Text: Textual AmendmentsF12S. 61(1)(ba) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(2); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3F13Words in s. 61(1)(e) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3F14Words in s. 61(1)(f) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(4); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3F15Words in s. 61(1)(g) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(5); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3F16S. 61(1)(h) substituted (1.7.2011) by Bribery Act 2010 (c. 23), s. 19(1), Sch. 1 para. 8 (with ss. 16, 19(5)); S.I. 2011/1418, art. 2F17S. 61(1)(i) inserted (27.4.2017 for specified purposes, 30.9.2017 in so far as not already in force ) by Criminal Finances Act 2017 (c. 22), ss. 51(1), 58(5)(6); S.I. 2017/739, reg. 3F18S. 61(1)(j) inserted (22.11.2018) by Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2018 (c. 13), s. 64(2), Sch. 3 para. 4 (with ss. 52(3), 53, 58); S.I. 2018/1213, reg. 2(f)F19Words in s. 61(2)(b) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(6); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3F20Words in s. 61(4) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 3(7); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI3S. 61 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I4S. 61 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)Disclosure noticesE+W+S62Disclosure noticesE+W+S(1)If it appears to the Investigating Authority—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that an offence to which this Chapter applies has been committed,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that any person has information (whether or not contained in a document) which relates to a matter relevant to the investigation of that offence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that there are reasonable grounds for believing that information which may be provided by that person in compliance with a disclosure notice is likely to be of substantial value (whether or not by itself) to that investigation,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he may give, or authorise an appropriate person to give, a disclosure notice to that person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F21(1A)If it appears to the Investigating Authority—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that any person has information (whether or not contained in a document) which relates to a matter relevant to a terrorist investigation, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that there are reasonable grounds for believing that information which may be provided by that person in compliance with a disclosure notice is likely to be of substantial value (whether or not by itself) to that investigation,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he may give, or authorise an appropriate person to give, a disclosure notice to that person.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In this Chapter “appropriate person” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a constable,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F22(b)a National Crime Agency officer who is for the time being designated under section 9 or 10 of the Crime and Courts Act 2013, or]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)an officer of Revenue and Customs.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F23But in the application of this Chapter to Northern Ireland, this subsection has effect as if paragraph (b) was omitted.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In this Chapter “disclosure notice” means a notice in writing requiring the person to whom it is given to do all or any of the following things in accordance with the specified requirements, namely—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)answer questions with respect to any matter relevant to the investigation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)provide information with respect to any such matter as is specified in the notice;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)produce such documents, or documents of such descriptions, relevant to the investigation as are specified in the notice.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In subsection (3) “the specified requirements” means such requirements specified in the disclosure notice as relate to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the time at or by which,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the place at which, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the manner in which,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the person to whom the notice is given is to do any of the things mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (c) of that subsection; and those requirements may include a requirement to do any of those things at once.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A disclosure notice must be signed or counter-signed by the Investigating Authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)This section has effect subject to section 64 (restrictions on requiring information etc.).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF21S. 62(1A) inserted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 33(3), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(b)F22S. 62(2)(b) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 159; S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F23Words in s. 62(2) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 4; S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI5S. 62 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)I6S. 62 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)63Production of documentsE+W+S(1)This section applies where a disclosure notice has been given under section 62.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An authorised person may—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)take copies of or extracts from any documents produced in compliance with the notice, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)require the person producing them to provide an explanation of any of them.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Documents so produced may be retained for so long as the Investigating Authority considers that it is necessary to retain them (rather than copies of them) in connection with the investigation for the purposes of which the disclosure notice was given.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the Investigating Authority has reasonable grounds for believing—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that any such documents may have to be produced for the purposes of any legal proceedings, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that they might otherwise be unavailable for those purposes,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: they may be retained until the proceedings are concluded.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)If a person who is required by a disclosure notice to produce any documents does not produce the documents in compliance with the notice, an authorised person may require that person to state, to the best of his knowledge and belief, where they are.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In this section “authorised person” means any appropriate person who either—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)is the person by whom the notice was given, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)is authorised by the Investigating Authority for the purposes of this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)This section has effect subject to section 64 (restrictions on requiring information etc.).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI7S. 63 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I8S. 63 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)64Restrictions on requiring information etc.E+W+S(1)A person may not be required under section 62 or 63—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to answer any privileged question,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to provide any privileged information, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)to produce any privileged document,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: except that a lawyer may be required to provide the name and address of a client of his.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A “privileged question” is a question which the person would be entitled to refuse to answer on grounds of legal professional privilege in proceedings in the High Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)“Privileged information” is information which the person would be entitled to refuse to provide on grounds of legal professional privilege in such proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A “privileged document” is a document which the person would be entitled to refuse to produce on grounds of legal professional privilege in such proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person may not be required under section 62 to produce any excluded material (as defined by section 11 of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (c. 60) [F24or, in relation to Northern Ireland, Article 13 of the Police and Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order 1989]).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In the application of this section to Scotland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)subsections (1) to (5) do not have effect, but
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person may not be required under section 62 or 63 to answer any question, provide any information or produce any document which he would be entitled, on grounds of legal privilege, to refuse to answer or (as the case may be) provide or produce.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In subsection (6)(b), “legal privilege” has the meaning given by section 412 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A person may not be required under section 62 or 63 to disclose any information or produce any document in respect of which he owes an obligation of confidence by virtue of carrying on any banking business, unless—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the person to whom the obligation of confidence is owed consents to the disclosure or production, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the requirement is made by, or in accordance with a specific authorisation given by, the Investigating Authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Subject to the preceding provisions, any requirement under section 62 or 63 has effect despite any restriction on disclosure (however imposed).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF24Words in s. 64(5) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 5; S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI9S. 64 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I10S. 64 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)65Restrictions on use of statementsE+W+S(1)A statement made by a person in response to a requirement imposed under section 62 or 63 (“the relevant statement”) may not be used in evidence against him in any criminal proceedings unless subsection (2) or (3) applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)This subsection applies where the person is being prosecuted—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)for an offence under section 67 of this Act, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)for an offence under section 5 of the Perjury Act 1911 (c. 6) (false statements made on oath otherwise than in judicial proceedings or made otherwise than on oath), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)for an offence under [F25section 44(2) of the Criminal Law (Consolidation) (Scotland) Act 1995 (c.39)] (false statutory declarations and other false statements without oath) or at common law for an offence of attempting to pervert the course, or defeat the ends, of justice[F26, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)for an offence under Article 10 of the Perjury (Northern Ireland) Order 1979 (false statements made otherwise than on oath).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)This subsection applies where the person is being prosecuted for some other offence and—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the person, when giving evidence in the proceedings, makes a statement inconsistent with the relevant statement, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the proceedings evidence relating to the relevant statement is adduced, or a question about it is asked, by or on behalf of the person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF25Words in s. 65(2)(c) substituted (S.) (28.3.2011) by Criminal Justice and Licensing (Scotland) Act 2010 (asp 13), s. 206(1), Sch. 7 para. 77; S.S.I. 2011/178, art. 2, Sch.F26S. 65(2)(d) and preceding word inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 6; S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI11S. 65 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I12S. 65 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)EnforcementE+W+S66Power to enter and seize documentsE+W+S(1)A justice of the peace may issue a warrant under this section if, on an information on oath laid by the Investigating Authority, he is satisfied—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that any of the conditions mentioned in subsection (2) is met in relation to any documents of a description specified in the information, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that the documents are on premises so specified.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The conditions are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that a person has been required by a disclosure notice to produce the documents but has not done so;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that it is not practicable to give a disclosure notice requiring their production;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that giving such a notice might seriously prejudice the investigation of an offence to which this Chapter applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A warrant under this section is a warrant authorising an appropriate person named in it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to enter and search the premises, using such force as is reasonably necessary;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to take possession of any documents appearing to be documents of a description specified in the information, or to take any other steps which appear to be necessary for preserving, or preventing interference with, any such documents;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in the case of any such documents consisting of information recorded otherwise than in legible form, to take possession of any computer disk or other electronic storage device which appears to contain the information in question, or to take any other steps which appear to be necessary for preserving, or preventing interference with, that information;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)to take copies of or extracts from any documents or information falling within paragraph (b) or (c);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)to require any person on the premises to provide an explanation of any such documents or information or to state where any such documents or information may be found;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)to require any such person to give the appropriate person such assistance as he may reasonably require for the taking of copies or extracts as mentioned in paragraph (d).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A person executing a warrant under this section may take other persons with him, if it appears to him to be necessary to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A warrant under this section must, if so required, be produced for inspection by the owner or occupier of the premises or anyone acting on his behalf.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If the premises are unoccupied or the occupier is temporarily absent, a person entering the premises under the authority of a warrant under this section must leave the premises as effectively secured against trespassers as he found them.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Where possession of any document or device is taken under this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the document may be retained for so long as the Investigating Authority considers that it is necessary to retain it (rather than a copy of it) in connection with the investigation for the purposes of which the warrant was sought, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the device may be retained for so long as he considers that it is necessary to retain it in connection with that investigation,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: as the case may be.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)If the Investigating Authority has reasonable grounds for believing—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that any such document or device may have to be produced for the purposes of any legal proceedings, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that it might otherwise be unavailable for those purposes,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it may be retained until the proceedings are concluded.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Nothing in this section authorises a person to take possession of, or make copies of or take extracts from, any document or information which, by virtue of section 64, could not be required to be produced or disclosed under section 62 or 63.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)In the application of this section to Scotland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)subsection (1) has effect as if, for the words from the beginning to “satisfied—”, there were substituted “ A sheriff may issue a warrant under this section, on the application of a procurator fiscal, if he is satisfied— ”;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)subsections (1)(a) and (3)(b) have effect as if, for “in the information”, there were substituted “ in the application ”; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)subsections (4) to (6) do not have effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F27(11)In the application of this section to Northern Ireland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)subsection (1) has effect as if, for the words from the beginning to “laid”, there were substituted “A lay magistrate may issue a warrant under this section if, on complaint on oath made”; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)subsections (1)(a) and (3)(b) have effect as if, for “in the information”, there were substituted “in the complaint”.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF27S. 66(11) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 7; S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI13S. 66 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I14S. 66 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)67Offences in connection with disclosure notices or search warrantsE+W+S(1)A person commits an offence if, without reasonable excuse, he fails to comply with any requirement imposed on him under section 62 or 63.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person commits an offence if, in purported compliance with any requirement imposed on him under section 62 or 63—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he makes a statement which is false or misleading, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he either knows that it is false or misleading or is reckless as to whether it is false or misleading.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “False or misleading” means false or misleading in a material particular.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person commits an offence if he wilfully obstructs any person in the exercise of any rights conferred by a warrant under section 66.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A person guilty of an offence under subsection (1) or (3) is liable on summary conviction—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under subsection (2) is liable—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or to a fine, or to both;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding [F28the general limit in a magistrates’ court] or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In the application of this section to Scotland, the reference to 51 weeks in subsection (4)(a) is to be read as a reference to 12 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F29(7)In the application of this section to Northern Ireland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the reference to 51 weeks in subsection (4)(a) is to be read as a reference to 6 months; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the reference to 12 months in subsection (5)(b) is to be read as a reference to 6 months.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF28Words in s. 67(5)(b) substituted (7.2.2023 at 12.00 p.m.) by The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 (Magistrates’ Court Sentencing Powers) Regulations 2023 (S.I. 2023/149), regs. 1(2), 2(1), Sch. Pt. 1F29S. 67(7) inserted (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), s. 31(3), Sch. 3 para. 8; S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Modifications etc. (not altering text)C38Ss. 60-67 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI15S. 67 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I16S. 67 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)SupplementaryU.K.68Procedure applicable to search warrantsU.K.In Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (c. 16) (powers of seizure to which section 50 applies) after paragraph 73E (inserted by the Human Tissue Act 2004 (c. 30)) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 200573FThe power of seizure conferred by section 66 of the Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (seizure of documents for purposes of investigation by DPP or other Investigating Authority).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI17S. 68 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)I18S. 68 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)69Manner in which disclosure notice may be givenE+W(1)This section provides for the manner in which a disclosure notice may be given under section 62.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The notice may be given to a person by—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)delivering it to him,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)leaving it at his proper address,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)sending it by post to him at that address.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The notice may be given—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in the case of a body corporate, to the secretary or clerk of that body;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the case of a partnership, to a partner or a person having the control or management of the partnership business;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in the case of an unincorporated association (other than a partnership), to an officer of the association.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purposes of this section and section 7 of the Interpretation Act 1978 (c. 30) (service of documents by post) in its application to this section, the proper address of a person is his usual or last-known address (whether residential or otherwise), except that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in the case of a body corporate or its secretary or clerk, it is the address of the registered office of that body or its principal office in the United Kingdom,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the case of a partnership, a partner or a person having the control or management of the partnership business, it is that of the principal office of the partnership in the United Kingdom, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in the case of an unincorporated association (other than a partnership) or an officer of the association, it is that of the principal office of the association in the United Kingdom.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)This section does not apply to Scotland.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Modifications etc. (not altering text)C39S. 69 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI19S. 69 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)70Interpretation of Chapter 1E+W+S(1)In this Chapter—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F30“act of terrorism” includes anything constituting an action taken for the purposes of terrorism, within the meaning of the Terrorism Act 2000 (see section 1(5) of that Act);]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “appropriate person” has the meaning given by section 62(2);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “the Investigating Authority” is to be construed in accordance with section 60(5) and (6);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “disclosure notice” has the meaning given by section 62(3);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “document” includes information recorded otherwise than in legible form.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F31“terrorism” has the same meaning as in the Terrorism Act 2000 (see section 1(1) to (4) of that Act);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “terrorist investigation” has the meaning given by section 60(7).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In relation to information recorded otherwise than in legible form, any reference in this Chapter to the production of documents is a reference to the production of a copy of the information in legible form.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF30Words in s. 70(1) inserted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 33(4)(a), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(b)F31Words in s. 70(1) inserted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 33(4)(b), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(b)Modifications etc. (not altering text)C40S. 70 extended (Northern Ireland) (1.12.2006) by Northern Ireland (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2006 (c. 33), ss. 26(1), 31(3); S.I. 2006/2966, art. 3Commencement InformationI20S. 70 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(a)I21S. 70 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)Chapter 2E+W+N.I.Offenders assisting investigations and prosecutions71Assistance by offender: immunity from prosecutionE+W+N.I.(1)If a specified prosecutor thinks that for the purposes of the investigation or prosecution of [F32an indictable offence or an offence triable either way] it is appropriate to offer any person immunity from prosecution [F33for any offence] he may give the person a written notice under this subsection (an “immunity notice”).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a person is given an immunity notice, no proceedings for an offence of a description specified in the notice may be brought against that person in England and Wales or Northern Ireland except in circumstances specified in the notice.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An immunity notice ceases to have effect in relation to the person to whom it is given if the person fails to comply with any conditions specified in the notice.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Each of the following is a specified prosecutor—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the Director of Public Prosecutions;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the Director of the Serious Fraud Office;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F35[F36(da)the Financial Conduct Authority;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (daa)the Prudential Regulation Authority;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (dab)the Bank of England, where the indictable offence or offence triable either way which is being investigated or prosecuted is an offence under the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000;]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (db)the [F37Secretary of State for Business and Trade], acting personally;]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)a prosecutor designated for the purposes of this section by a prosecutor mentioned in paragraphs (a) to [F38(db)].
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Director of Public Prosecutions or a person designated by him under subsection (4)(e) may not give an immunity notice in relation to proceedings in Northern Ireland.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland or a person designated by him under subsection (4)(e) may not give an immunity notice in relation to proceedings in England and Wales.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F39(6A)In exercising the power to designate a prosecutor under subsection (4)(e), the [F40Financial Conduct Authority, the Prudential Regulation Authority, the Bank of England] and the [F41Secretary of State for Business and Trade] may each designate only—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)one prosecutor (a “chief prosecutor”) to act at any one time, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)an alternative prosecutor (a “deputy prosecutor”) to act as a specified prosecutor—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)when the chief prosecutor is unavailable, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)during any period when no chief prosecutor is designated.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F42(6B)Paragraph 8(1) of Schedule 1ZA F43... to the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (arrangements for discharging functions) [F44and paragraph 17(1) of Schedule 6A to the Bank of England Act 1998 (delegation of functions)] do not apply to the exercise of the powers conferred on the Financial Conduct Authority or the Prudential Regulation Authority under this Chapter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6BA)Paragraph 11 of Schedule 1 to the Bank of England Act 1998 (power to delegate) does not apply to the exercise of the powers conferred on the Bank of England under this Chapter.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6C)An immunity notice may be given by the [F45Financial Conduct Authority, the Prudential Regulation Authority, the Bank of England], the [F46Secretary of State for Business and Trade] or a prosecutor designated by [F47any of them] under subsection (4)(e), only with the consent of the Attorney General.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)An immunity notice must not be given in relation to an offence under section 188 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (c. 40) (cartel offences).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

S.I. 2010/816, art. 2, Sch. para. 6F39S. 71(6A)-(6C) inserted (6.4.2010) by Coroners and Justice Act 2009 (c. 25), ss. 113(4), 182(5) (with s. 180); S.I. 2010/816, art. 2, Sch. para. 6F40Words in s. 71(6A) substituted (1.4.2013) by Financial Services Act 2012 (c. 21), s. 122(3), Sch. 18 para. 106(3) (with Sch. 20); S.I. 2013/423, art. 3, Sch.F41Words in s. 71(6A) substituted (3.5.2023) by The Secretaries of State for Energy Security and Net Zero, for Science, Innovation and Technology, for Business and Trade, and for Culture, Media and Sport and the Transfer of Functions (National Security and Investment Act 2021 etc) Order 2023 (S.I. 2023/424), art. 1(2), Sch. para. 12(3) (with art. 17)F42S. 71(6B)(6BA) substituted for s. 71(6B) (1.4.2013) by Financial Services Act 2012 (c. 21), s. 122(3), Sch. 18 para. 106(4) (with Sch. 20); S.I. 2013/423, art. 3, Sch.Modifications etc. (not altering text)C41S. 71: transfer of functions (3.5.2023) by The Secretaries of State for Energy Security and Net Zero, for Science, Innovation and Technology, for Business and Trade, and for Culture, Media and Sport and the Transfer of Functions (National Security and Investment Act 2021 etc) Order 2023 (S.I. 2023/424), arts. 1(2), 11(1) (with art. 17)Commencement InformationI22S. 71 in force at 1.4.2006 by S.I. 2006/378, art. 5(1)72Assistance by offender: undertakings as to use of evidenceE+W+N.I.(1)If a specified prosecutor thinks that for the purposes of the investigation or prosecution of [F48an indictable offence or an offence triable either way] it is appropriate to offer any person an undertaking that information of any description will not be used against the person in any proceedings to which this section applies he may give the person a written notice under this subsection (a “restricted use undertaking”).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)This section applies to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)[F49any] criminal proceedings;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)proceedings under Part 5 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If a person is given a restricted use undertaking the information described in the undertaking must not be used against that person in any proceedings to which this section applies brought in England and Wales or Northern Ireland except in the circumstances specified in the undertaking.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A restricted use undertaking ceases to have effect in relation to the person to whom it is given if the person fails to comply with any conditions specified in the undertaking.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland or a person designated by him under section 71(4)(e) may not give a restricted use undertaking in relation to proceedings in England and Wales.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Director of Public Prosecutions or a person designated by him under section 71(4)(e) may not give a restricted use undertaking in relation to proceedings in Northern Ireland.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Specified prosecutor must be construed in accordance with section 71(4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF48Words in s. 72(1) substituted (6.4.2010) by Coroners and Justice Act 2009 (c. 25), ss. 113(5), 182(5) (with s. 180); S.I. 2010/816, art. 2, Sch. para. 6F49Word in s. 72(2)(a) inserted (6.4.2010) by Coroners and Justice Act 2009 (c. 25), ss. 113(6), 182(5) (with s. 180); S.I. 2010/816, art. 2, Sch. para. 6Commencement InformationI23S. 72 in force at 1.4.2006 by S.I. 2006/378, art. 5(1)[F5073Assistance by defendant: reduction in sentenceE+W+N.I.(1)This section applies [F51in Northern Ireland] if a defendant—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)following a plea of guilty is either convicted of an offence in proceedings in the Crown Court or is committed to the Crown Court for sentence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)has, pursuant to a written agreement made with a specified prosecutor, assisted or offered to assist the investigator or prosecutor in relation to that or any other offence.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In determining what sentence to pass on the defendant the court may take into account the extent and nature of the assistance given or offered.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the court passes a sentence which is less than it would have passed but for the assistance given or offered, it must state in open court—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that it has passed a lesser sentence than it would otherwise have passed, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)what the greater sentence would have been.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Subsection (3) does not apply if the court thinks that it would not be in the public interest to disclose that the sentence has been discounted; but in such a case the court must give written notice of the matters specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (3) to both the prosecutor and the defendant.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Nothing in any enactment which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)requires that a minimum sentence is passed in respect of any offence or an offence of any description or by reference to the circumstances of any offender (whether or not the enactment also permits the court to pass a lesser sentence in particular circumstances), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the case of a sentence which is fixed by law, requires the court to take into account certain matters for the purposes of making an order which determines or has the effect of determining the minimum period of imprisonment which the offender must serve (whether or not the enactment also permits the court to fix a lesser period in particular circumstances),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: affects the power of a court to act under subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If, in determining what sentence to pass on the defendant, the court takes into account the extent and nature of the assistance given or offered as mentioned in subsection (2), that does not prevent the court from also taking account of any other matter which it is entitled by virtue of any other enactment to take account of for the purposes of determining—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the sentence, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the case of a sentence which is fixed by law, any minimum period of imprisonment which an offender must serve.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a reference to a sentence includes, in the case of a sentence which is fixed by law, a reference to the minimum period an offender is required to serve, and a reference to a lesser sentence must be construed accordingly;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a reference to imprisonment includes a reference to any other custodial sentence within the meaning of F53... Article 2 of the Criminal Justice (Northern Ireland) Order 1996 (S.I. 1996/ 3160).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)An agreement with a specified prosecutor may provide for assistance to be given to that prosecutor or to any other prosecutor.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)References to a specified prosecutor must be construed in accordance with section 71.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF50Ss. 73-75 repealed (E.W.) (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Schs. 28, 29 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F51Words in s. 73(1) inserted (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 24 para. 254 (with Sch. 24 para. 447, Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F52S. 73(7) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F53Words in s. 73(8)(b) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2Commencement InformationI24S. 73 in force at 1.4.2006 by S.I. 2006/378, art. 5(1)[F5074Assistance by defendant: review of sentenceE+W+N.I.(1)This section applies if [F54in Northern Ireland]—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the Crown Court has passed a sentence on a person in respect of an offence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the person falls within subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person falls within this subsection if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he receives a discounted sentence in consequence of his having offered in pursuance of a written agreement to give assistance to the prosecutor or investigator of an offence but he knowingly fails to any extent to give assistance in accordance with the agreement;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he receives a discounted sentence in consequence of his having offered in pursuance of a written agreement to give assistance to the prosecutor or investigator of an offence and, having given the assistance in accordance with the agreement, in pursuance of another written agreement gives or offers to give further assistance;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)he receives a sentence which is not discounted but in pursuance of a written agreement he subsequently gives or offers to give assistance to the prosecutor or investigator of an offence.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A specified prosecutor may at any time refer the case back to the court by which the sentence was passed if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the person is still serving his sentence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the specified prosecutor thinks it is in the interests of justice to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A case so referred must, if possible, be heard by the judge who passed the sentence to which the referral relates.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)If the court is satisfied that a person who falls within subsection (2)(a) knowingly failed to give the assistance it may substitute for the sentence to which the referral relates such greater sentence (not exceeding that which it would have passed but for the agreement to give assistance) as it thinks appropriate.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In a case of a person who falls within subsection (2)(b) or (c) the court may—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)take into account the extent and nature of the assistance given or offered;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)substitute for the sentence to which the referral relates such lesser sentence as it thinks appropriate.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Any part of the sentence to which the referral relates which the person has already served must be taken into account in determining when a greater or lesser sentence imposed by subsection (5) or (6) has been served.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A person in respect of whom a reference is made under this section and the specified prosecutor may with the leave of the Court of Appeal appeal to the Court of Appeal against the decision of the Crown Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)A discounted sentence is a sentence passed in pursuance of section 73 or subsection (6) above.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)References—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to a written agreement are to an agreement made in writing with a specified prosecutor;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to a specified prosecutor must be construed in accordance with section 71.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (12)In relation to any proceedings under this section,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland may, in relation to proceedings in Northern Ireland, make an order containing provision corresponding to any provision in the Criminal Appeal (Northern Ireland) Act 1980 (subject to any specified modifications).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (13)A person does not fall within subsection (2) if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he was convicted of an offence for which the sentence is fixed by law, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he did not plead guilty to the offence for which he was sentenced.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (15)Subsections (3) to (9) of section 73 apply for the purposes of this section as they apply for the purposes of that section and any reference in those subsections to subsection (2) of that section must be construed as a reference to subsection (6) of this section.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF50Ss. 73-75 repealed (E.W.) (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Schs. 28, 29 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F54Words in s. 74(1) inserted (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 24 para. 255 (with Sch. 24 para. 447, Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F55S. 74(9) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F56Words in s. 74(12) substituted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 19(2) (with arts. 28-31)F57S. 74(12)(a) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2F58S. 74(14) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2Commencement InformationI25S. 74 in force at 1.4.2006 by S.I. 2006/378, art. 5(1) (with art. 5(2))[F5075Proceedings under section 74: exclusion of publicE+W+N.I.(1)This section applies to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)any proceedings relating to a reference made under section 74(3), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any other proceedings arising in consequence of such proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The court in which the proceedings will be or are being heard may make such order as it thinks appropriate—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to exclude from the proceedings any person who does not fall within subsection (4);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to give such directions as it thinks appropriate prohibiting the publication of any matter relating to the proceedings (including the fact that the reference has been made).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An order under subsection (2) may be made only to the extent that the court thinks—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that it is necessary to do so to protect the safety of any person, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that it is in the interests of justice.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The following persons fall within this subsection—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a member or officer of the court;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a party to the proceedings;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)counsel or a solicitor for a party to the proceedings;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)a person otherwise directly concerned with the proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)This section does not affect any other power which the court has by virtue of any rule of law or other enactment—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to exclude any person from proceedings, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to restrict the publication of any matter relating to proceedings.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF64Ss. 79-81 omitted (1.3.2016) by virtue of Serious Crime Act 2015 (c. 9), s. 88(1), Sch. 4 para. 71 (with s. 86(7)-(9)); S.I. 2016/148, reg. 3(g)Chapter 4U.K.Protection of witnesses and other persons82Protection [F65of persons involved in investigations or proceedings] [F65arrangements for persons at risk] E+W+S(1)A protection provider may make such arrangements as he considers appropriate for the purpose of protecting [F66a person of a description specified in Schedule 5 if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the protection provider considers that the person's safety is at risk by virtue of his being a person of a description so specified, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the person is ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F66any person if he reasonably believes that the person's safety is at risk in view of the criminal conduct or possible criminal conduct of another person.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A protection provider may vary or cancel any arrangements made by him under subsection (1) if he considers it appropriate to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If a protection provider makes arrangements under subsection (1) or cancels arrangements made under that subsection, he must record that he has done so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In determining whether to make arrangements under subsection (1), or to vary or cancel arrangements made under that subsection, a protection provider must, in particular, have regard to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the nature and extent of the risk to the person's safety,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the cost of the arrangements,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the likelihood that the person, and any person associated with him, will be able to adjust to any change in their circumstances which may arise from the making of the arrangements or from their variation or cancellation (as the case may be), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)if the person is or might be a witness in legal proceedings (whether or not in the United Kingdom), the nature of the proceedings and the importance of his being a witness in those proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A protection provider is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a chief officer of a police force in England and Wales;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F67(b)the chief constable of the Police Service of Scotland;]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F68(d)the Director General of the National Crime Agency;]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)any of the Commissioners for Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (g)a person designated by a person mentioned in any of the preceding paragraphs to exercise his functions under this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F70(5A)In subsection (1), “criminal conduct” means conduct which constitutes an offence in England and Wales or Scotland, or would do if it occurred there.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5B)Nothing in this section prevents a protection provider from making arrangements under this section for the protection of a person where non-statutory arrangements have already been made in respect of that person.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F71(6)The Secretary of State may, after consulting the Scottish Ministers [F72and the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland], by order amend Schedule 5 so as to add, modify or omit any entry.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Nothing in this section affects any power which a person has (otherwise than by virtue of this section) to make arrangements for the protection of another person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

(13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(2)(a), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18F66Words in s. 82(1) substituted (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(2)(b), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18F67S. 82(5)(b) substituted (1.4.2013) by The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(13)(a)F68S. 82(5)(d) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 160; S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F69S. 82(5)(f) omitted (1.4.2013) by virtue of The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(13)(b)F70S. 82(5A)(5B) inserted (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(2)(c), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18F71S. 82(6) repealed (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(2)(d), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18F72Words in s. 82(6) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 20 (with arts. 28-31)Commencement InformationI27S. 82 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I28S. 82 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)83Joint arrangementsU.K.(1)Arrangements may be made under section 82(1) by two or more protection providers acting jointly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If arrangements are made jointly by virtue of subsection (1), any powers conferred on a protection provider by this Chapter are exercisable in relation to the arrangements by—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)all of the protection providers acting together, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)one of the protection providers, or some of the protection providers acting together, with the agreement of the others.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Nothing in this section or in section 84 affects any power which a protection provider has to request or obtain assistance from another protection provider.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI29S. 83 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)I30S. 83 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)84Transfer of responsibility to other protection providerU.K.(1)A protection provider who makes arrangements under section 82(1) may agree with another protection provider that, as from a date specified in the agreement—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the protection provider will cease to discharge any responsibilities which he has in relation to the arrangements, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the other protection provider will discharge those responsibilities instead.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Any such agreement may include provision for the making of payments in respect of any costs incurred or likely to be incurred in consequence of the agreement.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If an agreement is made under subsection (1), any powers conferred on a protection provider by this Chapter (including the power conferred by subsection (1)) are, as from the date specified in the agreement, exercisable by the other protection provider as if he had made the arrangements under section 82(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Each protection provider who makes an agreement under subsection (1) must record that he has done so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI31S. 84 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I32S. 84 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)85Duty to assist protection providersU.K.(1)This section applies if a protection provider requests assistance from a public authority in connection with the making of arrangements under section 82(1) or the implementation, variation or cancellation of such arrangements.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The public authority must take reasonable steps to provide the assistance requested.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)“Public authority” includes any person certain of whose functions are of a public nature but does not include—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a court or tribunal,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)either House of Parliament or a person exercising functions in connection with proceedings in Parliament, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the Scottish Parliament or a person exercising functions in connection with proceedings in the Scottish Parliament.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI33S. 85 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I34S. 85 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)86Offence of disclosing information about protection arrangementsU.K.(1)A person commits an offence if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he discloses information which relates to the making of arrangements under section 82(1) or to the implementation, variation or cancellation of such arrangements, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he knows or suspects that the information relates to the making of such arrangements or to their implementation, variation or cancellation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, to a fine or to both;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding [F73the general limit in a magistrates’ court], to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In the application of this section to Scotland or Northern Ireland, the reference in subsection (2)(b) to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF73Words in s. 86(2)(b) substituted (7.2.2023 at 12.00 p.m.) by The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 (Magistrates’ Court Sentencing Powers) Regulations 2023 (S.I. 2023/149), regs. 1(2), 2(1), Sch. Pt. 1Commencement InformationI35S. 86 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)I36S. 86 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)87Defences to liability under section 86U.K.(1)A person (P) is not guilty of an offence under section 86 if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)at the time when P disclosed the information, he was or had been a protected person,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the information related only to arrangements made for the protection of P or for the protection of P and a person associated with him, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)at the time when P disclosed the information, it was not likely that its disclosure would endanger the safety of any person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person (D) is not guilty of an offence under section 86 if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)D disclosed the information with the agreement of a person (P) who, at the time the information was disclosed, was or had been a protected person,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the information related only to arrangements made for the protection of P or for the protection of P and a person associated with him, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)at the time when D disclosed the information, it was not likely that its disclosure would endanger the safety of any person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person is not guilty of an offence under section 86 if he disclosed the information for the purposes of safeguarding national security or for the purposes of the prevention, detection or investigation of crime.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A person is not guilty of an offence under section 86 if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)at the time when he disclosed the information, he was a protection provider or involved in the making of arrangements under section 82(1) or in the implementation, variation or cancellation of such arrangements, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he disclosed the information for the purposes of the making, implementation, variation or cancellation of such arrangements.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may by order make provision prescribing circumstances in which a person who discloses information as mentioned in section 86(1) is not guilty in England and Wales F74... of an offence under that section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Scottish Ministers may by order make provision prescribing circumstances in which a person who discloses information as mentioned in section 86(1) is not guilty in Scotland of an offence under that section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F75(6A)The Department of Justice in Northern Ireland may by order make provision prescribing circumstances in which a person who discloses information as mentioned in section 86(1) is not guilty in Northern Ireland of an offence under that section.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)If sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue with respect to a defence under or by virtue of this section, the court or jury must assume that the defence is satisfied unless the prosecution proves beyond reasonable doubt that it is not.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF74Words in s. 87(5) omitted (12.4.2010) by virtue of The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 21(a) (with arts. 28-31)F75S. 87(6A) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 21(b) (with arts. 28-31)Commencement InformationI37S. 87 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)I38S. 87 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)88Offences of disclosing information relating to persons assuming new identityU.K.(1)A person (P) commits an offence if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)P is or has been a protected person,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)P assumed a new identity in pursuance of arrangements made under section 82(1),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)P discloses information which indicates that he assumed, or might have assumed, a new identity, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)P knows or suspects that the information disclosed by him indicates that he assumed, or might have assumed, a new identity.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person (D) commits an offence if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)D discloses information which relates to a person (P) who is or has been a protected person,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)P assumed a new identity in pursuance of arrangements made under section 82(1),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the information disclosed by D indicates that P assumed, or might have assumed, a new identity, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)D knows or suspects—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)that P is or has been a protected person, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)that the information disclosed by D indicates that P assumed, or might have assumed, a new identity.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, to a fine or to both;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding [F76the general limit in a magistrates’ court], to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In the application of this section to Scotland or Northern Ireland, the reference in subsection (3)(b) to 12 months is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may by order make provision prescribing circumstances in which a person who discloses information as mentioned in subsection (1) or (2) of section 88 is not guilty in England and Wales F77... of an offence under that subsection.
