Text: Textual AmendmentsF77Words in s. 89(5) omitted (12.4.2010) by virtue of The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 22(a) (with arts. 28-31)F78S. 89(6A) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 22(b) (with arts. 28-31)Commencement InformationI41S. 89 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I42S. 89 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)90Protection from liabilityU.K.(1)This section applies if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)arrangements are made for the protection of a person under section 82(1), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the protected person assumes a new identity in pursuance of the arrangements.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)No proceedings (whether civil or criminal) may be brought against a person to whom this section applies in respect of the making by him of a false or misleading representation if the representation—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)relates to the protected person, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)is made solely for the purpose of ensuring that the arrangements made for him to assume a new identity are, or continue to be, effective.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The persons to whom this section applies are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the protected person;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person who is associated with the protected person;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)a protection provider;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)a person involved in the making of arrangements under section 82(1) or in the implementation, variation or cancellation of such arrangements.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI43S. 90 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I44S. 90 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)91Transitional provisionU.K.[F79(1)This section applies to arrangements which were, at any time before the commencement of section 82, made by a protection provider, or any person acting with his authority, for the purpose of protecting a person of a description specified in Schedule 5.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If the following three conditions are satisfied, the arrangements are to be treated as having been made by the protection provider under section 82(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The first condition is that the protection provider could have made the arrangements under section 82(1) had it been in force at the time when the arrangements were made.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The second condition is that the arrangements were in operation immediately before the commencement of section 82.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The third condition is that the protection provider determines that it is appropriate to treat the arrangements as having been made under section 82(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)A determination under subsection (5) may be made at any time before the end of the period of six months beginning with the day on which section 82 comes into force.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)A protection provider must make a record of a determination under subsection (5).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)Subsection (9) applies if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)at any time before the commencement of section 82, arrangements were made by a person specified in subsection (11), or any person acting with the authority of such a person, for the purpose of protecting a person of a description specified in Schedule 5, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)functions in relation to the arrangements are, at any time before the end of the period of six months mentioned in subsection (6), exercisable by a protection provider.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)The provision made by subsections (1) to (7) applies in relation to the arrangements as if they had been made by the protection provider.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)Accordingly, if the three conditions mentioned in subsections (3) to (5) are satisfied in relation to the arrangements, they are to be treated, by virtue of subsection (2), as having been made by the protection provider under section 82(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)The persons specified in this subsection are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the Director General of the National Criminal Intelligence Service;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the Director General of the National Crime Squad;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)any of the Commissioners of Her Majesty's Customs and Excise.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF79Ss. 91, 92 repealed (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(3), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18Commencement InformationI45S. 91 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I46S. 91 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)92Transitional provision: supplementalU.K.[F79(1)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)“the arrangements” are arrangements which are treated as having been made by a protection provider by virtue of section 91(2), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)“the relevant date” is the date of the record made by the protection provider, in relation to the arrangements, in pursuance of section 91(7).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person does not commit an offence under section 86(1) by disclosing information relating to the arrangements unless the information is disclosed on or after the relevant date.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)But it is immaterial whether the information relates to something done in connection with the arrangements before or on or after the relevant date.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A person does not commit an offence under section 88(1) or (2) by disclosing information relating to a person who assumed a new identity in pursuance of the arrangements unless the information is disclosed on or after the relevant date.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)But it is immaterial whether the person assumed a new identity before or on or after the relevant date.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Section 90 applies in relation to a false or misleading representation relating to a person who assumed a new identity in pursuance of the arrangements only if the false or misleading representation is made on or after the relevant date.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)But it is immaterial whether the person assumed a new identity before or on or after the relevant date.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF79Ss. 91, 92 repealed (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(3), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18Commencement InformationI47S. 92 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)I48S. 92 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)93Provision of informationU.K.(1)This section applies if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a protection provider makes arrangements under section 82(1), [F80or]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)[F80a protection provider determines under section 91(5) that it is appropriate to treat arrangements to which that section applies as having been made under section 82(1).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The protection provider must inform the person to whom the arrangements relate of the provisions of this Chapter as they apply in relation to the arrangements.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the protection provider considers that the person would be unable to understand the information, by reason of his age or of any incapacity, the information must instead be given to a person who appears to the protection provider—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to be interested in the welfare of the person to whom the arrangements relate, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to be the appropriate person to whom to give the information.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If arrangements are made jointly under section 82(1) (by virtue of section 83), the protection providers involved in the arrangements must nominate one of those protection providers to perform the duties imposed by this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF80S. 93(1)(b) and preceding word repealed (E.W.S.) (13.5.2014) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), ss. 178(4), 185(1) (with s. 178(7)); S.I. 2014/949, art. 3, Sch. para. 18Commencement InformationI49S. 93 in force at 1.4.2006 except to the extent that it extends to S. by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(1)I50S. 93 in force at 1.4.2006 for S. by S.S.I. 2006/166, art. 2(1)(b)94Interpretation of Chapter 4U.K.(1)This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)“Protection provider” is to be construed in accordance with section 82.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person is a protected person if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)arrangements have been made for his protection under subsection (1) of section 82, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the arrangements have not been cancelled under subsection (2) of that section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A person is associated with another person if any of the following apply—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)they are members of the same family;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)they live in the same household;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)they have lived in the same household.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person assumes a new identity if either or both of the following apply—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he becomes known by a different name;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he makes representations about his personal history or circumstances which are false or misleading.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)A reference to a person who is a witness in legal proceedings includes a reference to a person who provides any information or any document or other thing which might be used in evidence in those proceedings or which (whether or not admissible as evidence in those proceedings)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)might tend to confirm evidence which will or might be admitted in those proceedings,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)might be referred to in evidence given in those proceedings by another witness, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)might be used as the basis for any cross examination in the course of those proceedings,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: and a reference to a person who might be, or to a person who has been, a witness in legal proceedings is to be construed accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)A reference to a person who is a witness in legal proceedings does not include a reference to a person who is an accused person in criminal proceedings unless he is a witness for the prosecution and a reference to a person who might be, or to a person who has been, a witness in legal proceedings is to be construed accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A reference to a person who is or has been a member of staff of an organisation includes a reference to a person who is or has been seconded to the organisation to serve as a member of its staff.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An order under subsection (1) [F89or (1A)] may amend, repeal, revoke or otherwise modify any provision of Part 2 or 4 of the 2002 Act [F91(as the case may be)] or any other enactment relating to, or to things done under or for the purposes of, [F92that Part (or any provision of that Part)].
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF83Word in s. 97(1) omitted (12.4.2010) by virtue of The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(2)(a) (with arts. 28-31)F84S. 97(1)(b) omitted (12.4.2010) by virtue of The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(2)(b) (with arts. 28-31)F85Words in s. 97(1) omitted (12.4.2010) by virtue of The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(2)(c) (with arts. 28-31)F86S. 97(1ZA)(1ZB) inserted (1.6.2015) by Serious Crime Act 2015 (c. 9), ss. 40(2), 88(1); S.I. 2015/820, reg. 3(m)F87S. 97(1A) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(3) (with arts. 28-31)F88Words in s. 97(2) omitted (1.6.2015) by virtue of Serious Crime Act 2015 (c. 9), ss. 40(3), 88(1); S.I. 2015/820, reg. 3(m)F89Words in s. 97(2)(3) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(4) (with arts. 28-31)F90S. 97(2A) inserted (1.6.2015) by Serious Crime Act 2015 (c. 9), ss. 40(4), 88(1); S.I. 2015/820, reg. 3(m)F91Words in s. 97(3) inserted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(5)(a) (with arts. 28-31)F92Words in s. 97(3) substituted (12.4.2010) by The Northern Ireland Act 1998 (Devolution of Policing and Justice Functions) Order 2010 (S.I. 2010/976), art. 1(2), Sch. 15 para. 23(5)(b) (with arts. 28-31)Commencement InformationI54S. 97 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(a)98Civil recovery: freezing ordersU.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), after section 245 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Property freezing orders (England and Wales and Northern Ireland)U.K.245AApplication for property freezing order(1)Where the enforcement authority may take proceedings for a recovery order in the High Court, the authority may apply to the court for a property freezing order (whether before or after starting the proceedings).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A property freezing order is an order that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)specifies or describes the property to which it applies, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)subject to any exclusions (see section 245C(1)(b) and (2)), prohibits any person to whose property the order applies from in any way dealing with the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An application for a property freezing order may be made without notice if the circumstances are such that notice of the application would prejudice any right of the enforcement authority to obtain a recovery order in respect of any property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The court may make a property freezing order on an application if it is satisfied that the condition in subsection (5) is met and, where applicable, that the condition in subsection (6) is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The first condition is that there is a good arguable case—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that the property to which the application for the order relates is or includes recoverable property, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that, if any of it is not recoverable property, it is associated property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The second condition is that, if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the property to which the application for the order relates includes property alleged to be associated property, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the enforcement authority has not established the identity of the person who holds it,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the authority has taken all reasonable steps to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245BVariation and setting aside of order(1)The court may at any time vary or set aside a property freezing order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If the court makes an interim receiving order that applies to all of the property to which a property freezing order applies, it must set aside the property freezing order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the court makes an interim receiving order that applies to some but not all of the property to which a property freezing order applies, it must vary the property freezing order so as to exclude any property to which the interim receiving order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the court decides that any property to which a property freezing order applies is neither recoverable property nor associated property, it must vary the order so as to exclude the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Before exercising power under this Chapter to vary or set aside a property freezing order, the court must (as well as giving the parties to the proceedings an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by its decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Subsection (5) does not apply where the court is acting as required by subsection (2) or (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245CExclusions(1)The power to vary a property freezing order includes (in particular) power to make exclusions as follows—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)power to exclude property from the order, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)power, otherwise than by excluding property from the order, to make exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies (other than exclusions of property from the order) may also be made when the order is made.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An exclusion may, in particular, make provision for the purpose of enabling any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to meet his reasonable living expenses, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to carry on any trade, business, profession or occupation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)An exclusion may be made subject to conditions.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Where the court exercises the power to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses that he has incurred, or may incur, in respect of proceedings under this Part, it must ensure that the exclusion—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)is limited to reasonable legal expenses that the person has reasonably incurred or that he reasonably incurs,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)specifies the total amount that may be released for legal expenses in pursuance of the exclusion, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)is made subject to the required conditions (see section 286A) in addition to any conditions imposed under subsection (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The court, in deciding whether to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses of his in respect of proceedings under this Part—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)must have regard (in particular) to the desirability of the person being represented in any proceedings under this Part in which he is a participant, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)must, where the person is the respondent, disregard the possibility that legal representation of the person in any such proceedings might, were an exclusion not made, be funded by the Legal Services Commission or the Northern Ireland Legal Services Commission.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)If excluded property is not specified in the order it must be described in the order in general terms.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)The power to make exclusions must, subject to subsection (6), be exercised with a view to ensuring, so far as practicable, that the satisfaction of any right of the enforcement authority to recover the property obtained through unlawful conduct is not unduly prejudiced.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Subsection (8) does not apply where the court is acting as required by section 245B(3) or (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245DRestriction on proceedings and remedies(1)While a property freezing order has effect—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the court may stay any action, execution or other legal process in respect of the property to which the order applies, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)no distress may be levied against the property to which the order applies except with the leave of the court and subject to any terms the court may impose.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a court (whether the High Court or any other court) in which proceedings are pending in respect of any property is satisfied that a property freezing order has been applied for or made in respect of the property, it may either stay the proceedings or allow them to continue on any terms it thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If a property freezing order applies to a tenancy of any premises, no landlord or other person to whom rent is payable may exercise the right of forfeiture by peaceable re-entry in relation to the premises in respect of any failure by the tenant to comply with any term or condition of the tenancy, except with the leave of the court and subject to any terms the court may impose.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Before exercising any power conferred by this section, the court must (as well as giving the parties to any of the proceedings concerned an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by the court's decision.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), after section 255 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Prohibitory property orders (Scotland)U.K.255AApplication for prohibitory property order(1)Where the enforcement authority may take proceedings for a recovery order in the Court of Session, the authority may apply to the court for a prohibitory property order (whether before or after starting the proceedings).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A prohibitory property order is an order that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)specifies or describes the property to which it applies, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)subject to any exclusions (see section 255C(1)(b) and (2)), prohibits any person to whose property the order applies from in any way dealing with the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An application for a prohibitory property order may be made without notice if the circumstances are such that notice of the application would prejudice any right of the enforcement authority to obtain a recovery order in respect of any property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The court may make a prohibitory property order on an application if it is satisfied that the condition in subsection (5) is met and, where applicable, that the condition in subsection (6) is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The first condition is that there is a good arguable case—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that the property to which the application for the order relates is or includes recoverable property, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that, if any of it is not recoverable property, it is associated property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The second condition is that, if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the property to which the application for the order relates includes property alleged to be associated property, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the enforcement authority has not established the identity of the person who holds it,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the authority has taken all reasonable steps to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255BVariation and recall of prohibitory property order(1)The court may at any time vary or recall a prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If the court makes an interim administration order that applies to all of the property to which a prohibitory property order applies, it must recall the prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the court makes an interim administration order that applies to some but not all of the property to which a prohibitory property order applies, it must vary the prohibitory property order so as to exclude any property to which the interim administration order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the court decides that any property to which a prohibitory property order applies is neither recoverable property nor associated property, it must vary the order so as to exclude the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Before exercising power under this Chapter to vary or recall a prohibitory property order, the court must (as well as giving the parties to the proceedings an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by its decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Subsection (5) does not apply where the court is acting as required by subsection (2) or (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255CExclusions(1)The power to vary a prohibitory property order includes (in particular) power to make exclusions as follows—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)power to exclude property from the order, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)power, otherwise than by excluding property from the order, to make exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies (other than exclusions of property from the order) may also be made when the order is made.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An exclusion may, in particular, make provision for the purpose of enabling any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to meet his reasonable living expenses, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to carry on any trade, business, profession or occupation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)An exclusion may be made subject to conditions.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An exclusion may not be made for the purpose of enabling any person to meet any legal expenses in respect of proceedings under this Part.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If excluded property is not specified in the order it must be described in the order in general terms.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The power to make exclusions must be exercised with a view to ensuring, so far as practicable, that the satisfaction of any right of the enforcement authority to recover the property obtained through unlawful conduct is not unduly prejudiced.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)Subsection (7) does not apply where the court is acting as required by section 255B(3) or (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255DRestriction on proceedings and remedies(1)While a prohibitory property order has effect the court may sist any action, execution or other legal process in respect of the property to which the order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a court (whether the Court of Session or any other court) in which proceedings are pending in respect of any property is satisfied that a prohibitory property order has been applied for or made in respect of the property, it may either sist the proceedings or allow them to continue on any terms it thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Before exercising any power conferred by this section, the court must (as well as giving the parties to any of the proceedings concerned an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by the court's decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255EArrestment of property affected by prohibitory property order(1)On the application of the enforcement authority the Court of Session may, in relation to moveable recoverable property to which a prohibitory property order applies (whether generally or to such of it as is specified in the application), grant warrant for arrestment.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An application under subsection (1) may be made at the same time as the application for the prohibitory property order or at any time thereafter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Such a warrant for arrestment may be granted only if the property would be arrestable if the person entitled to it were a debtor.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A warrant under subsection (1) has effect as if granted on the dependence of an action for debt at the instance of the enforcement authority against the person and may be executed, recalled, loosed or restricted accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An arrestment executed under this section ceases to have effect when, or in so far as, the prohibitory property order ceases to apply in respect of the property in relation to which the warrant for arrestment was granted.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If an arrestment ceases to have effect to any extent by virtue of subsection (5) the enforcement authority must apply to the Court of Session for an order recalling or, as the case may be, restricting the arrestment.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255FInhibition of property affected by prohibitory property order(1)On the application of the enforcement authority, the Court of Session may, in relation to the property mentioned in subsection (2), grant warrant for inhibition against any person specified in a prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)That property is heritable property situated in Scotland to which the prohibitory property order applies (whether generally or to such of it as is specified in the application).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The warrant for inhibition—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)has effect as if granted on the dependence of an action for debt by the enforcement authority against the person and may be executed, recalled, loosed or restricted accordingly, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)has the effect of letters of inhibition and must forthwith be registered by the enforcement authority in the register of inhibitions and adjudications.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Section 155 of the Titles to Land Consolidation (Scotland) Act 1868 (c. 101) (effective date of inhibition) applies in relation to an inhibition for which warrant is granted under subsection (1) as it applies to an inhibition by separate letters or contained in a summons.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An inhibition executed under this section ceases to have effect when, or in so far as, the prohibitory property order ceases to apply in respect of the property in relation to which the warrant for inhibition was granted.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If an inhibition ceases to have effect to any extent by virtue of subsection (5) the enforcement authority must—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)apply for the recall or, as the case may be, the restriction of the inhibition, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)ensure that the recall or restriction is reflected in the register of inhibitions and adjudications.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI55S. 98(1) in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(a)I56S. 98(2) in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 2(a)99Civil recovery: interim receivers' expenses etc.U.K.(1)The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 280 (civil recovery orders: applying realised proceeds), after subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3)The Director may apply a sum received by him under subsection (2) in making payment of the remuneration and expenses of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the trustee, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any interim receiver appointed in, or in anticipation of, the proceedings for the recovery order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Subsection (3)(a) does not apply in relation to the remuneration of the trustee if the trustee is a member of the staff of the Agency.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 284 (payment of interim administrator or trustee (Scotland))—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the existing words become subsection (1), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)after that subsection insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2)The Scottish Ministers may apply a sum received by them under section 280(2) in making payment of such fees or expenses.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the fees of a trustee for civil recovery if the trustee is a member of their staff.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF93S. 99(4) repealed (1.4.2008) by Serious Crime Act 2007 (c. 27), s. 94(1), Sch. 14; S.I. 2008/755, art. 2(1)(d) (with arts. 3-14)Commencement InformationI57S. 99(1)(4) in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(b)I58S. 99(2)(3) in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 2(1)(b)100Detention of seized cash: meaning of “48 hours”U.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), Chapter 3 of Part 5 (civil recovery of cash in summary proceedings) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 295 (detention of seized cash, initially for 48 hours), after subsection (1) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)The period of 48 hours mentioned in subsection (1) is to be calculated in accordance with subsection (1B).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)In calculating a period of 48 hours in accordance with this subsection, no account shall be taken of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)any Saturday or Sunday,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)Christmas Day,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)Good Friday,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)any day that is a bank holiday under the Banking and Financial Dealings Act 1971 in the part of the United Kingdom within which the cash is seized, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)any day prescribed under section 8(2) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 as a court holiday in a sheriff court in the sheriff court district within which the cash is seized.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In sections 290(6), 296(1) and 302(2), after “48 hours” insert “ (calculated in accordance with section 295(1B)) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI59S. 100 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 2(1)(c)101Appeal in proceedings for forfeiture of cashU.K.(1)For section 299 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (appeal against forfeiture of cash) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “299Appeal against decision under section 298(1)Any party to proceedings for an order for the forfeiture of cash under section 298 who is aggrieved by an order under that section or by the decision of the court not to make such an order may appeal—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in relation to England and Wales, to the Crown Court;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in relation to Scotland, to the Sheriff Principal;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in relation to Northern Ireland, to a county court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An appeal under subsection (1) must be made before the end of the period of 30 days starting with the day on which the court makes the order or decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The court hearing the appeal may make any order it thinks appropriate.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the court upholds an appeal against an order forfeiting the cash, it may order the release of the cash.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)This section does not apply to a decision of a court not to order the forfeiture of cash under section 298 of that Act taken before this section comes into force.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI60S. 101 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 2(1)(d) (with art. 2(2))102Money laundering: defence where overseas conduct is legal under local lawU.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), Part 7 (money laundering) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 327 (concealing etc.), after subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)Nor does a person commit an offence under subsection (1) if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he knows, or believes on reasonable grounds, that the relevant criminal conduct occurred in a particular country or territory outside the United Kingdom, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the relevant criminal conduct—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)was not, at the time it occurred, unlawful under the criminal law then applying in that country or territory, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)is not of a description prescribed by an order made by the Secretary of State.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2B)In subsection (2A) “the relevant criminal conduct” is the criminal conduct by reference to which the property concerned is criminal property.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI61S. 102 in force at 15.5.2006 by S.I. 2006/1085, art. 3103Money laundering: threshold amountsU.K.(1)The Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 327 (concealing etc.), after subsection (2B) (which is inserted by section 102 of this Act) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2C)A deposit-taking body that does an act mentioned in paragraph (c) or (d) of subsection (1) does not commit an offence under that subsection if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it does the act in operating an account maintained with it, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the value of the criminal property concerned is less than the threshold amount determined under section 339A for the act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 328 (arrangements), after subsection (4) (which is inserted by section 102 of this Act) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(5)A deposit-taking body that does an act mentioned in subsection (1) does not commit an offence under that subsection if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it does the act in operating an account maintained with it, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the arrangement facilitates the acquisition, retention, use or control of criminal property of a value that is less than the threshold amount determined under section 339A for the act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In section 329 (acquisition, use and possession), after subsection (2B) (which is inserted by section 102 of this Act) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2C)A deposit-taking body that does an act mentioned in subsection (1) does not commit an offence under that subsection if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it does the act in operating an account maintained with it, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the value of the criminal property concerned is less than the threshold amount determined under section 339A for the act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In Part 7 (money laundering), after section 339 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Threshold amountsU.K.339AThreshold amounts(1)This section applies for the purposes of sections 327(2C), 328(5) and 329(2C).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The threshold amount for acts done by a deposit-taking body in operating an account is £250 unless a higher amount is specified under the following provisions of this section (in which event it is that higher amount).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An officer of Revenue and Customs, or a constable, may specify the threshold amount for acts done by a deposit-taking body in operating an account—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)when he gives consent, or gives notice refusing consent, to the deposit-taking body's doing of an act mentioned in section 327(1), 328(1) or 329(1) in opening, or operating, the account or a related account, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)on a request from the deposit-taking body.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Where the threshold amount for acts done in operating an account is specified under subsection (3) or this subsection, an officer of Revenue and Customs, or a constable, may vary the amount (whether on a request from the deposit-taking body or otherwise) by specifying a different amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Different threshold amounts may be specified under subsections (3) and (4) for different acts done in operating the same account.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The amount specified under subsection (3) or (4) as the threshold amount for acts done in operating an account must, when specified, not be less than the amount specified in subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The Secretary of State may by order vary the amount for the time being specified in subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)For the purposes of this section, an account is related to another if each is maintained with the same deposit-taking body and there is a person who, in relation to each account, is the person or one of the persons entitled to instruct the body as respects the operation of the account.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In section 340 (interpretation of Part 7), after subsection (13) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(14)“Deposit-taking body” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a business which engages in the activity of accepting deposits, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the National Savings Bank.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In section 459(4)(a) and (6)(a) (provision for certain orders to be subject to affirmative procedure), after “309,” insert “ 339A(7), ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI62S. 103 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(c)104Money laundering: disclosures to identify persons and propertyU.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), Part 7 (money laundering) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 330(1) (regulated sector: failure to disclose: offence committed if three conditions satisfied), for “each of the following three conditions is satisfied” substitute “ the conditions in subsections (2) to (4) are satisfied ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)For section 330(4) to (6) (the required disclosure) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3A)The third condition is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that he can identify the other person mentioned in subsection (2) or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that he believes, or it is reasonable to expect him to believe, that the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3) will or may assist in identifying that other person or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The fourth condition is that he does not make the required disclosure to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a nominated officer, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by the Director General of the Serious Organised Crime Agency,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: as soon as is practicable after the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3) comes to him.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The required disclosure is a disclosure of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (2), if he knows it,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the whereabouts of the laundered property, so far as he knows it, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5A)The laundered property is the property forming the subject-matter of the money laundering that he knows or suspects, or has reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting, that other person to be engaged in.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)But he does not commit an offence under this section if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he has a reasonable excuse for not making the required disclosure,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he is a professional legal adviser and—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)if he knows either of the things mentioned in subsection (5)(a) and (b), he knows the thing because of information or other matter that came to him in privileged circumstances, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3) came to him in privileged circumstances, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)subsection (7) applies to him.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For section 331(4) to (6) (failure to disclose: nominated officers in the regulated sector: the required disclosure) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3A)The third condition is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that he knows the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (2), or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property, in consequence of a disclosure made under section 330,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that that other person, or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property, can be identified from the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that he believes, or it is reasonable to expect him to believe, that the information or other matter will or may assist in identifying that other person or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The fourth condition is that he does not make the required disclosure to a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by the Director General of the Serious Organised Crime Agency as soon as is practicable after the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3) comes to him.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The required disclosure is a disclosure of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (2), if disclosed to him under section 330,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the whereabouts of the laundered property, so far as disclosed to him under section 330, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5A)The laundered property is the property forming the subject-matter of the money laundering that he knows or suspects, or has reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting, that other person to be engaged in.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)But he does not commit an offence under this section if he has a reasonable excuse for not making the required disclosure.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In section 332(3) (failure to disclose: other nominated officers: the second condition), for “section 337 or 338” substitute “ the applicable section ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For section 332(4) to (6) (the required disclosure) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3A)The third condition is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that he knows the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (2), or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property, in consequence of a disclosure made under the applicable section,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that that other person, or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property, can be identified from the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that he believes, or it is reasonable to expect him to believe, that the information or other matter will or may assist in identifying that other person or the whereabouts of any of the laundered property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The fourth condition is that he does not make the required disclosure to a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by the Director General of the Serious Organised Crime Agency as soon as is practicable after the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3) comes to him.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The required disclosure is a disclosure of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (2), if disclosed to him under the applicable section,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the whereabouts of the laundered property, so far as disclosed to him under the applicable section, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the information or other matter mentioned in subsection (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5A)The laundered property is the property forming the subject-matter of the money laundering that he knows or suspects that other person to be engaged in.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5B)The applicable section is section 337 or, as the case may be, section 338.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)But he does not commit an offence under this section if he has a reasonable excuse for not making the required disclosure.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In section 337 (protected disclosures), after subsection (4) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(4A)Where a disclosure consists of a disclosure protected under subsection (1) and a disclosure of either or both of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the identity of the other person mentioned in subsection (3), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the whereabouts of property forming the subject-matter of the money laundering that the discloser knows or suspects, or has reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting, that other person to be engaged in,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the disclosure of the thing mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) (as well as the disclosure protected under subsection (1)) is not to be taken to breach any restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI63S. 104 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(c) (with art. 3(4))105Money laundering: form and manner of disclosuresU.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), Part 7 (money laundering) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In each of sections 330(9)(b), 337(5)(b) and 338(5)(b) (disclosure to nominated officer is ineffective if employer's procedures not followed), omit “and in accordance with the procedure established by the employer for the purpose”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 334 (penalties), after subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3)A person guilty of an offence under section 339(1A) is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In section 338(1) (authorised disclosures), omit paragraph (b) (disclosure must be made in prescribed form and manner) but not the “and” at the end.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In section 339 (form and manner of disclosures), for subsections (2) and (3) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)A person commits an offence if he makes a disclosure under section 330, 331, 332 or 338 otherwise than in the form prescribed under subsection (1) or otherwise than in the manner so prescribed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)But a person does not commit an offence under subsection (1A) if he has a reasonable excuse for making the disclosure otherwise than in the form prescribed under subsection (1) or (as the case may be) otherwise than in the manner so prescribed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The power under subsection (1) to prescribe the form in which a disclosure must be made includes power to provide for the form to include a request to a person making a disclosure that the person provide information specified or described in the form if he has not provided it in making the disclosure.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Where under subsection (2) a request is included in a form prescribed under subsection (1), the form must—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)state that there is no obligation to comply with the request, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)explain the protection conferred by subsection (4) on a person who complies with the request.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI64S. 105 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(c)106Money laundering: miscellaneous amendmentsU.K.(1)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002, Part 7 (money laundering) is amended as follows.

Text: (2)In section 330 (regulated sector: failure to disclose), after subsection (9) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(9A)But a disclosure which satisfies paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (9) is not to be taken as a disclosure to a nominated officer if the person making the disclosure—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)is a professional legal adviser,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)makes it for the purpose of obtaining advice about making a disclosure under this section, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)does not intend it to be a disclosure under this section.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 337(5)(a) (disclosure to person nominated to receive disclosures under section 337), after “disclosures under” insert “ section 330 or ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In section 338(1)(c) (first or second condition must be satisfied for disclosure to be authorised), for “or second” substitute “ , second or third ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In section 338 (authorised disclosures), after subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)The second condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the disclosure is made while the alleged offender is doing the prohibited act,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he began to do the act at a time when, because he did not then know or suspect that the property constituted or represented a person's benefit from criminal conduct, the act was not a prohibited act, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the disclosure is made on his own initiative and as soon as is practicable after he first knows or suspects that the property constitutes or represents a person's benefit from criminal conduct.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In section 338(3) (the second condition), for “second” substitute “ third ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI67S. 108 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(d)109Minor and consequential amendments relating to Chapter 6E+WSchedule 6, which contains minor and consequential amendments relating to provisions of this Chapter, has effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI68S. 109 in force at 1.8.2005 for specified purposes by S.I. 2005/2026, art. 2(a)I69S. 109 in force at 1.1.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 2(c)I70S. 109 in force at 1.1.2006 in so far as not already in force by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(b) Part 3 U.K.Police powers etc.Powers of arrestE+W110Powers of arrestE+W(1)For section 24 of PACE (arrest without warrant for arrestable offences) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “24Arrest without warrant: constables(1)A constable may arrest without a warrant—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)anyone who is about to commit an offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)anyone who is in the act of committing an offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)anyone whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting to be about to commit an offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)anyone whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting to be committing an offence.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a constable has reasonable grounds for suspecting that an offence has been committed, he may arrest without a warrant anyone whom he has reasonable grounds to suspect of being guilty of it.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If an offence has been committed, a constable may arrest without a warrant—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)anyone who is guilty of the offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)anyone whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting to be guilty of it.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)But the power of summary arrest conferred by subsection (1), (2) or (3) is exercisable only if the constable has reasonable grounds for believing that for any of the reasons mentioned in subsection (5) it is necessary to arrest the person in question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The reasons are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to enable the name of the person in question to be ascertained (in the case where the constable does not know, and cannot readily ascertain, the person's name, or has reasonable grounds for doubting whether a name given by the person as his name is his real name);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)correspondingly as regards the person's address;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)to prevent the person in question—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)causing physical injury to himself or any other person;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)suffering physical injury;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iii)causing loss of or damage to property;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iv)committing an offence against public decency (subject to subsection (6)); or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (v)causing an unlawful obstruction of the highway;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)to protect a child or other vulnerable person from the person in question;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)to allow the prompt and effective investigation of the offence or of the conduct of the person in question;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)to prevent any prosecution for the offence from being hindered by the disappearance of the person in question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Subsection (5)(c)(iv) applies only where members of the public going about their normal business cannot reasonably be expected to avoid the person in question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 24AArrest without warrant: other persons(1)A person other than a constable may arrest without a warrant—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)anyone who is in the act of committing an indictable offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)anyone whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting to be committing an indictable offence.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Where an indictable offence has been committed, a person other than a constable may arrest without a warrant—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)anyone who is guilty of the offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)anyone whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting to be guilty of it.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)But the power of summary arrest conferred by subsection (1) or (2) is exercisable only if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the person making the arrest has reasonable grounds for believing that for any of the reasons mentioned in subsection (4) it is necessary to arrest the person in question; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)it appears to the person making the arrest that it is not reasonably practicable for a constable to make it instead.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The reasons are to prevent the person in question—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)causing physical injury to himself or any other person;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)suffering physical injury;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)causing loss of or damage to property; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)making off before a constable can assume responsibility for him.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Section 25 of PACE (general arrest conditions) shall cease to have effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 66 of PACE (codes of practice), in subsection (1)(a)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)omit “or” at the end of sub-paragraph (i),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)at the end of sub-paragraph (ii) insert “or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iii)to arrest a person;”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The sections 24 and 24A of PACE substituted by subsection (1) are to have effect in relation to any offence whenever committed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI71S. 110 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(m)111Powers of arrest: supplementaryE+WSchedule 7, which supplements section 110 by providing for the repeal of certain enactments (including some which are spent) and by making further supplementary provision, has effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI72S. 111 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(m)Exclusion zonesE+W112Power to direct a person to leave a placeE+W(1)A constable may direct a person to leave a place if he believes, on reasonable grounds, that the person is in the place at a time when he would be prohibited from entering it by virtue of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)an order to which subsection (2) applies, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a condition to which subsection (3) applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)This subsection applies to an order which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)was made, by virtue of any enactment, following the person's conviction of an offence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)prohibits the person from entering the place or from doing so during a period specified in the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)This subsection applies to a condition which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)was imposed, by virtue of any enactment, as a condition of the person's release from a prison in which he was serving a sentence of imprisonment following his conviction of an offence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)prohibits the person from entering the place or from doing so during a period specified in the condition.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A direction under this section may be given orally.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Any person who knowingly contravenes a direction given to him under this section is guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks or to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)In subsection (3)(a)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)“sentence of imprisonment” and “prison” are to be construed in accordance with section 62(5) of the Criminal Justice and Court Services Act 2000 (c. 43);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the reference to a release from prison includes a reference to a temporary release.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)In this section, “place” includes an area.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)This section applies whether or not the order or condition mentioned in subsection (1) was made or imposed before or after the commencement of this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF94S. 112(6) repealed (1.1.2006) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), s. 178(8)(8), Sch. 17 Pt. 2; S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(t)(u)(lxi)F95S. 112(7) repealed (1.1.2006) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), s. 178(8)(8), Sch. 17 Pt. 2; S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(t)(u)(lxi)Commencement InformationI73S. 112 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(e)Search warrantsE+W113Search warrants: premisesE+W(1)PACE is amended as follows.

Text: (2)Section 8 (power to authorise entry and search of premises) is amended as provided in subsections (3) and (4).

Text: (3)In subsection (1)—

Text: (a)in paragraph (b), for “specified in the application” substitute “ mentioned in subsection (1A) below ”,

Text: Commencement InformationI74S. 113 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(n)114Search warrants: other amendmentsE+W(1)PACE is amended as follows.

Text: (2)In section 8 (power to authorise entry and search of premises), after the subsection (1B) inserted by section 113(4) of this Act insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1C)The warrant may authorise entry to and search of premises on more than one occasion if, on the application, the justice of the peace is satisfied that it is necessary to authorise multiple entries in order to achieve the purpose for which he issues the warrant.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1D)If it authorises multiple entries, the number of entries authorised may be unlimited, or limited to a maximum.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Section 15 (search warrants—safeguards) is amended as provided in subsections (4) to (7).

Text: (4)In subsection (2)(a)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)omit “and” at the end of sub-paragraph (i),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)at the end of sub-paragraph (ii) insert “ and ”,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)after that sub-paragraph insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(iii)if the application is for a warrant authorising entry and search on more than one occasion, the ground on which he applies for such a warrant, and whether he seeks a warrant authorising an unlimited number of entries, or (if not) the maximum number of entries desired;”.

Text: (6)After subsection (5) insert—

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
