Text: Commencement InformationI76S. 115 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(f)Photographing of suspects etc.E+W116Photographing of suspects etc.E+W(1)Section 64A of PACE (photographing of suspects etc.) is amended as follows.

Text: (2)After subsection (1) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)A person falling within subsection (1B) below may, on the occasion of the relevant event referred to in subsection (1B), be photographed elsewhere than at a police station—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)with the appropriate consent; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)A person falls within this subsection if he has been—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)arrested by a constable for an offence;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)taken into custody by a constable after being arrested for an offence by a person other than a constable;

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)given a penalty notice by a constable in uniform under Chapter 1 of Part 1 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001, a penalty notice by a constable under section 444A of the Education Act 1996, or a fixed penalty notice by a constable in uniform under section 54 of the Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)given a notice in relation to a relevant fixed penalty offence (within the meaning of paragraph 1 of Schedule 4 to the 2002 Act) by a community support officer by virtue of a designation applying that paragraph to him; or

Text: Commencement InformationI77S. 116(1)(3)-(5) in force at 1.8.2005 by S.I. 2005/2026, art. 2(c)I78S. 116(2) in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(o)Fingerprints and footwear impressionsE+W117FingerprintsE+W(1)Section 61 of PACE (fingerprinting) is amended as provided in subsections (2) to (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)After subsection (6) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(6A)A constable may take a person's fingerprints without the appropriate consent if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the constable reasonably suspects that the person is committing or attempting to commit an offence, or has committed or attempted to commit an offence; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)either of the two conditions mentioned in subsection (6B) is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6B)The conditions are that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the name of the person is unknown to, and cannot be readily ascertained by, the constable;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the constable has reasonable grounds for doubting whether a name furnished by the person as his name is his real name.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6C)The taking of fingerprints by virtue of subsection (6A) does not count for any of the purposes of this Act as taking them in the course of the investigation of an offence by the police.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In subsection (7), for “or (6)” substitute “ , (6) or (6A) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)after “police station,” insert “ or by virtue of subsection (6A) at a place other than a police station, ”,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in paragraph (a), after “an officer” insert “ (or, in a subsection (6A) case, the constable) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In section 63A of PACE (fingerprints and samples: supplementary provisions)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “((1ZA))Fingerprints taken by virtue of section 61(6A) above may be checked against other fingerprints to which the person seeking to check has access and which are held by or on behalf of any one or more relevant law-enforcement authorities or which are held in connection with or as a result of an investigation of an offence.”,

Text: Textual AmendmentsF96S. 117(6)-(10) repealed (31.10.2013) by Protection of Freedoms Act 2012 (c. 9), s. 120, Sch. 10 Pt. 1 (with s. 97); S.I. 2013/2104, art. 3(d)Commencement InformationI79S. 117(1)(2) in force at 7.3.2011 by S.I. 2011/410, art. 2(a)I80S. 117(4)(a) in force at 7.3.2011 by S.I. 2011/410, art. 2(b)I81S. 117(5) in force at 7.3.2011 by S.I. 2011/410, art. 2(c)118Impressions of footwearE+W(1)PACE is amended as provided in subsections (2) to (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)After section 61 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “61AImpressions of footwear(1)Except as provided by this section, no impression of a person's footwear may be taken without the appropriate consent.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Consent to the taking of an impression of a person's footwear must be in writing if it is given at a time when he is at a police station.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Where a person is detained at a police station, an impression of his footwear may be taken without the appropriate consent if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he is detained in consequence of his arrest for a recordable offence, or has been charged with a recordable offence, or informed that he will be reported for a recordable offence; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he has not had an impression taken of his footwear in the course of the investigation of the offence by the police.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Where a person mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (3) above has already had an impression taken of his footwear in the course of the investigation of the offence by the police, that fact shall be disregarded for the purposes of that subsection if the impression of his footwear taken previously is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)incomplete; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)is not of sufficient quality to allow satisfactory analysis, comparison or matching (whether in the case in question or generally).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)If an impression of a person's footwear is taken at a police station, whether with or without the appropriate consent—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)before it is taken, an officer shall inform him that it may be the subject of a speculative search; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the fact that the person has been informed of this possibility shall be recorded as soon as is practicable after the impression has been taken, and if he is detained at a police station, the record shall be made on his custody record.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In a case where, by virtue of subsection (3) above, an impression of a person's footwear is taken without the appropriate consent—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he shall be told the reason before it is taken; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the reason shall be recorded on his custody record as soon as is practicable after the impression is taken.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The power to take an impression of the footwear of a person detained at a police station without the appropriate consent shall be exercisable by any constable.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)Nothing in this section applies to any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)arrested or detained under the terrorism provisions;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)arrested under an extradition arrest power.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI89S. 124 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(l) Part 4 U.K.Public order and conduct in public places etc.HarassmentE+W125Harassment intended to deter lawful activitiesE+W(1)The Protection from Harassment Act 1997 (c. 40) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In section 1 (prohibition of harassment)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)after subsection (1) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)A person must not pursue a course of conduct —
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)which involves harassment of two or more persons, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)which he knows or ought to know involves harassment of those persons, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)by which he intends to persuade any person (whether or not one of those mentioned above)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)not to do something that he is entitled or required to do, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)to do something that he is not under any obligation to do.”;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in subsection (2), after “amounts to” insert “ or involves ” and after “amounted to” insert “ or involved ”;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in subsection (3), after “Subsection (1)” insert “ or (1A) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In section 2(1) (offence of harassment) for “section 1” substitute “ section 1(1) or (1A) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In section 3(1) (civil remedy) for “section 1” substitute “ section 1(1) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)After section 3 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “3AInjunctions to protect persons from harassment within section 1(1A)(1)This section applies where there is an actual or apprehended breach of section 1(1A) by any person (“the relevant person”).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In such a case—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)any person who is or may be a victim of the course of conduct in question, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any person who is or may be a person falling within section 1(1A)(c),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: may apply to the High Court or a county court for an injunction restraining the relevant person from pursuing any conduct which amounts to harassment in relation to any person or persons mentioned or described in the injunction.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Section 3(3) to (9) apply in relation to an injunction granted under subsection (2) above as they apply in relation to an injunction granted as mentioned in section 3(3)(a).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In section 7 (interpretation of sections 1 to 5)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(3)A “course of conduct” must involve—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in the case of conduct in relation to a single person (see section 1(1)), conduct on at least two occasions in relation to that person, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in the case of conduct in relation to two or more persons (see section 1(1A)), conduct on at least one occasion in relation to each of those persons.”; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)after subsection (4) add—

Text: Textual AmendmentsF105S. 125(6) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2Commencement InformationI90S. 125 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(m)126Harassment etc. of a person in his homeE+W(1)After section 42 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (c. 16) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “42AOffence of harassment etc. of a person in his home(1)A person commits an offence if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that person is present outside or in the vicinity of any premises that are used by any individual (“the resident”) as his dwelling;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that person is present there for the purpose (by his presence or otherwise) of representing to the resident or another individual (whether or not one who uses the premises as his dwelling), or of persuading the resident or such another individual—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)that he should not do something that he is entitled or required to do; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)that he should do something that he is not under any obligation to do;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)intends his presence to amount to the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, the resident; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)knows or ought to know that his presence is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, the resident; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)the presence of that person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)amounts to the harassment of, or causes alarm or distress to, any person falling within subsection (2); or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, any such person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person falls within this subsection if he is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the resident,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person in the resident's dwelling, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)a person in another dwelling in the vicinity of the resident's dwelling.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The references in subsection (1)(c) and (d) to a person's presence are references to his presence either alone or together with that of any other persons who are also present.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purposes of this section a person (A) ought to know that his presence is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, a resident if a reasonable person in possession of the same information would think that A's presence was likely to have that effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable, on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks or to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (alteration of penalties for summary offences), the reference in subsection (5) to 51 weeks is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section “dwelling” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Public Order Act 1986.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF106S. 126(2) repealed (1.1.2006) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), s. 178(8)(8), Sch. 17 Pt. 2; S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(t)(u)(lxi)F107S. 126(3) repealed (1.1.2006) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), s. 178(8)(8), Sch. 17 Pt. 2; S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(t)(u)(lxi)Commencement InformationI91S. 126 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(m)127Harassment etc: police direction to stay away from person's homeE+W(1)Section 42 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (c. 16) (police directions stopping harassment of a person in his home) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)For subsection (4) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(4)The requirements that may be imposed by a direction under this section include—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a requirement to leave the vicinity of the premises in question, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a requirement to leave that vicinity and not to return to it within such period as the constable may specify, not being longer than 3 months;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: and (in either case) the requirement to leave the vicinity may be to do so immediately or after a specified period of time.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In subsection (7), for “contravenes a direction given to him under this section” substitute “ fails to comply with a requirement in a direction given to him under this section (other than a requirement under subsection (4)(b)) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)After subsection (7) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(7A)Any person to whom a constable has given a direction including a requirement under subsection (4)(b) commits an offence if he—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)returns to the vicinity of the premises in question within the period specified in the direction beginning with the date on which the direction is given; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)does so for the purpose described in subsection (1)(b).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7B)A person guilty of an offence under subsection (7A) shall be liable, on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks or to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7C)In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (alteration of penalties for summary offences), the reference in subsection (7B) to 51 weeks is to be read as a reference to 6 months.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI92S. 127 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(m)Trespass on designated siteU.K.128Offence of trespassing on designated siteE+W+N.I.(1)A person commits an offence if he enters, or is on, any [F108protected] site in England and Wales or Northern Ireland as a trespasser.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F109(1A)In this section “protected site” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a nuclear site; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a designated site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)In this section “nuclear site” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)so much of any premises in respect of which a nuclear site licence (within the meaning of the Nuclear Installations Act 1965) is for the time being in force as lies within the outer perimeter of the protection provided for those premises; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)so much of any other premises of which premises falling within paragraph (a) form a part as lies within that outer perimeter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1C)For this purpose—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the outer perimeter of the protection provided for any premises is the line of the outermost fences, walls or other obstacles provided or relied on for protecting those premises from intruders; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that line shall be determined on the assumption that every gate, door or other barrier across a way through a fence, wall or other obstacle is closed.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A “designated site” means a site—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)specified or described (in any way) in an order made by the Secretary of State, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)designated for the purposes of this section by the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The Secretary of State may only designate a site for the purposes of this section if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it is comprised in Crown land; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)it is comprised in land belonging to Her Majesty in Her private capacity or to the immediate heir to the Throne in his private capacity; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)it appears to the Secretary of State that it is appropriate to designate the site in the interests of national security.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under this section to prove that he did not know, and had no reasonable cause to suspect, that the site in relation to which the offence is alleged to have been committed was a [F110protected] site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary conviction—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)No proceedings for an offence under this section may be instituted against any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in England and Wales, except by or with the consent of the Attorney General, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in Northern Ireland, except by or with the consent of the Attorney General for Northern Ireland.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)For the purposes of this section a person who is on any [F111protected] site as a trespasser does not cease to be a trespasser by virtue of being allowed time to leave the site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)“site” means the whole or part of any building or buildings, or any land, or both;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)“Crown land” means land in which there is a Crown interest or a Duchy interest.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)For this purpose—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Crown interest” means an interest belonging to Her Majesty in right of the Crown, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Duchy interest” means an interest belonging to Her Majesty in right of the Duchy of Lancaster or belonging to the Duchy of Cornwall.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)In the application of this section to Northern Ireland, the reference to 51 weeks in subsection (5)(a) is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF108Word in s. 128(1) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F109S. 128(1A)-(1C) inserted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(3), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F110Word in s. 128(4) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F111Word in s. 128(7) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)Modifications etc. (not altering text)C42S. 128 extended (N.I.) (1.7.2005) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), ss. 130(2), 178(8); S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(n)Commencement InformationI93S. 128 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(n)129Corresponding Scottish offenceS(1)A person commits an offence if he enters, or is on, any [F112protected] Scottish site without lawful authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F113(1A)In this section ‘protected Scottish site’ means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a nuclear site in Scotland; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a designated Scottish site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)In this section ‘nuclear site’ means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)so much of any premises in respect of which a nuclear site licence (within the meaning of the Nuclear Installations Act 1965) is for the time being in force as lies within the outer perimeter of the protection provided for those premises; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)so much of any other premises of which premises falling within paragraph (a) form a part as lies within that outer perimeter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1C)For this purpose—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the outer perimeter of the protection provided for any premises is the line of the outermost fences, walls or other obstacles provided or relied on for protecting those premises from intruders; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that line shall be determined on the assumption that every gate, door or other barrier across a way through a fence, wall or other obstacle is closed.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A “designated Scottish site” means a site in Scotland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)specified or described (in any way) in an order made by the Secretary of State, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)designated for the purposes of this section by the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The Secretary of State may only designate a site for the purposes of this section if it appears to him that it is appropriate to designate the site in the interests of national security.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under this section to prove that he did not know, and had no reasonable cause to suspect, that the site in relation to which the offence is alleged to have been committed was a [F114protected] Scottish site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary conviction—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For the purposes of subsection (1), a person who is on any [F115protected] Scottish site without lawful authority does not acquire lawful authority by virtue of being allowed time to leave the site.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section “site” means the whole or part of any building or buildings, or any land, or both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF112Word in s. 129(1) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F113S. 129(1A)-(1C) inserted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(4), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F114Word in s. 129(4) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)F115Word in s. 129(6) substituted (13.4.2006) by Terrorism Act 2006 (c. 11), ss. 12(2), 39(2); S.I. 2006/1013, art. 2(2)(a)Commencement InformationI94S. 129 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(n)130Designated sites: powers of arrestU.K.F116(1). . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Text: (2)An offence under section 128 is to be treated as an arrestable offence for the purposes of the Police and Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 (S.I. 1989/1341 (N.I. 12)).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF116S. 130(1) repealed (1.1.2006) by Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15), s. 178(8)(8), Sch. 17 Pt. 2; S.I. 2005/3495, art. 2(1)(t)(u)(lxi)F117S. 130(3) repealed (S.) (25.1.2018) by Criminal Justice (Scotland) Act 2016 (asp 1), s. 117(2), sch. 2 para. 19; S.S.I. 2017/345, art. 3, sch.Commencement InformationI95S. 130 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(n)131Designated sites: accessU.K.(1)The following provisions do not apply to land in respect of which a designation order is in force—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)section 2(1) of the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 (c. 37) (rights of public in relation to access land),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)Part III of the Countryside (Northern Ireland) Order 1983 (S.I. 1983/1895 (N.I. 18)) (access to open country), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)section 1 of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 2) (access rights).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The Secretary of State may take such steps as he considers appropriate to inform the public of the effect of any designation order, including, in particular, displaying notices on or near the site to which the order relates.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)But the Secretary of State may only—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)display any such notice, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)take any other steps under subsection (2),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: in or on any building or land, if the appropriate person consents.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The “appropriate person” is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a person appearing to the Secretary of State to have a sufficient interest in the building or land to consent to the notice being displayed or the steps being taken, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person acting on behalf of such a person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In this section a “designation order” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in relation to England and Wales or Northern Ireland, an order under section 128, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in relation to Scotland, an order under section 129.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI99S. 144 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 2 Part 5 U.K.MiscellaneousProtection of activities of certain organisationsE+W145Interference with contractual relationships so as to harm animal research organisationE+W(1)A person (A) commits an offence if, with the intention of harming an animal research organisation, he—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)does a relevant act, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)threatens that he or somebody else will do a relevant act,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: in circumstances in which that act or threat is intended or likely to cause a second person (B) to take any of the steps in subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The steps are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)not to perform any contractual obligation owed by B to a third person (C) (whether or not such non-performance amounts to a breach of contract);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to terminate any contract B has with C;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)not to enter into a contract with C.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)For the purposes of this section, a “relevant act” is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)an act amounting to a criminal offence, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a tortious act causing B to suffer loss or damage of any description;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: but paragraph (b) does not include an act which is actionable on the ground only that it induces another person to break a contract with B.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purposes of this section, “contract” includes any other arrangement (and “contractual” is to be read accordingly).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)For the purposes of this section, to “harm” an animal research organisation means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)to cause the organisation to suffer loss or damage of any description, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to prevent or hinder the carrying out by the organisation of any of its activities.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)This section does not apply to any act done wholly or mainly in contemplation or furtherance of a trade dispute.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In subsection (6) “trade dispute” has the same meaning as in Part 4 of the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (c. 52), except that section 218 of that Act shall be read as if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it made provision corresponding to section 244(4) of that Act, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in subsection (5), the definition of “worker” included any person falling within paragraph (b) of the definition of “worker” in section 244(5).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI100S. 145 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(t)146Intimidation of persons connected with animal research organisationE+W(1)A person (A) commits an offence if, with the intention of causing a second person (B) to abstain from doing something which B is entitled to do (or to do something which B is entitled to abstain from doing)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)A threatens B that A or somebody else will do a relevant act, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)A does so wholly or mainly because B is a person falling within subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person falls within this subsection if he is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)an employee or officer of an animal research organisation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a student at an educational establishment that is an animal research organisation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)a lessor or licensor of any premises occupied by an animal research organisation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)a person with a financial interest in, or who provides financial assistance to, an animal research organisation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)a customer or supplier of an animal research organisation;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)a person who is contemplating becoming someone within paragraph (c), (d) or (e);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (g)a person who is, or is contemplating becoming, a customer or supplier of someone within paragraph (c), (d), (e) or (f);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (h)an employee or officer of someone within paragraph (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)a person with a financial interest in, or who provides financial assistance to, someone within paragraph (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (j)a spouse, civil partner, friend or relative of, or a person who is known personally to, someone within any of paragraphs (a) to (i);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (k)a person who is, or is contemplating becoming, a customer or supplier of someone within paragraph (a), (b), (h), (i) or (j); or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (l)an employer of someone within paragraph (j).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)For the purposes of this section, an “officer” of an animal research organisation or a person includes—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)where the organisation or person is a body corporate, a director, manager or secretary;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)where the organisation or person is a charity, a [F122charity trustee (within the meaning of the Charities Act 2011)];
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)where the organisation or person is a partnership, a partner.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purposes of this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a person is a customer or supplier of another person if he purchases goods, services or facilities from, or (as the case may be) supplies goods, services or facilities to, that other; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)“supplier” includes a person who supplies services in pursuance of any enactment that requires or authorises such services to be provided.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)For the purposes of this section, a “relevant act” is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)an act amounting to a criminal offence, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a tortious act causing B or another person to suffer loss or damage of any description.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Secretary of State may by order amend this section so as to include within subsection (2) any description of persons framed by reference to their connection with—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)an animal research organisation, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any description of persons for the time being mentioned in that subsection.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)This section does not apply to any act done wholly or mainly in contemplation or furtherance of a trade dispute.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)In subsection (7) “trade dispute” has the meaning given by section 145(7).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF122Words in s. 146(3)(b) substituted (14.3.2012) by Charities Act 2011 (c. 25), s. 355, Sch. 7 para. 103 (with s. 20(2), Sch. 8)Commencement InformationI101S. 146 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(t)147Penalty for offences under sections 145 and 146E+W(1)A person guilty of an offence under section 145 or 146 is liable—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding [F123the general limit in a magistrates’ court] or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or to both;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years or to a fine, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)No proceedings for an offence under either of those sections may be instituted except by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF123Words in s. 147(1)(a) substituted (7.2.2023 at 12.00 p.m.) by The Judicial Review and Courts Act 2022 (Magistrates’ Court Sentencing Powers) Regulations 2023 (S.I. 2023/149), regs. 1(2), 2(1), Sch. Pt. 1Commencement InformationI102S. 147 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(t)148Animal research organisationsE+W(1)For the purposes of sections 145 and 146 “animal research organisation” means any person or organisation falling within subsection [F124(1A),] (2) or (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F125(1A)A person or organisation falls within this subsection if the person or organisation holds a licence granted under section 2C of the 1986 Act (licensing of undertakings involving the use of animals for scientific procedures).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person or organisation falls within this subsection if he or it is the owner, lessee or licensee of premises constituting or [F126including a place specified in a licence granted under that section or under section 5 of the 1986 Act (licensing of projects involving the use of animals for scientific procedures).]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person or organisation falls within this subsection if he or it employs, or engages under a contract for services, any of the following in his capacity as such—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F127(za)the holder of a licence granted under section 2C of the 1986 Act,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (zb)a person specified under section 2C(5) of that Act,]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the holder of a personal licence granted under section 4 of the 1986 Act, [F128or]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the holder of a project licence granted under section 5 of that Act,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The Secretary of State may by order amend this section so as to include a reference to any description of persons whom he considers to be involved in, or to have a direct connection with persons who are involved in, the application of regulated procedures.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “the 1986 Act” means the Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 (c. 14);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “organisation” includes any institution, trust, undertaking or association of persons;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “premises” includes any place within the meaning of the 1986 Act;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “regulated procedures” has the meaning given by section 2 of the 1986 Act.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF124Word in s. 148(1) inserted (1.1.2013) by The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(2) (with Sch. 3)F125S. 148(1A) inserted (1.1.2013) by The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(3) (with Sch. 3)F126Words in s. 148(2) substituted (1.1.2013) by The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(4) (with Sch. 3)F127S. 148(3)(za)(zb) inserted (1.1.2013) by The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(5)(a) (with Sch. 3)F128Word in s. 148(3)(a) inserted (1.1.2013) by The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(5)(b) (with Sch. 3)F129S. 148(3)(c)(d) omitted (1.1.2013) by virtue of The Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 Amendment Regulations 2012 (S.I. 2012/3039), regs. 1(2), 28(5)(c) (with Sch. 3)Commencement InformationI103S. 148 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(t)149Extension of sections 145 to 147E+W(1)The Secretary of State may by order provide for sections 145, 146 and 147 to apply in relation to persons or organisations of a description specified in the order as they apply in relation to animal research organisations.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The Secretary of State may, however, only make an order under this section if satisfied that a series of acts has taken place and—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that those acts were directed at persons or organisations of the description specified in the order or at persons having a connection with them, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that, if those persons or organisations had been animal research organisations, those acts would have constituted offences under section 145 or 146.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In this section “organisation” and “animal research organisation” have the meanings given by section 148.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI104S. 149 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(t)Vehicle registration and insurance and road traffic offencesU.K.150Offence in respect of incorrectly registered vehiclesU.K.(1)After section 43B of the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994 (c. 22) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Offence in respect of incorrectly registered vehiclesU.K.43COffence of using an incorrectly registered vehicle(1)A person is guilty of an offence if, on a public road or in a public place, he uses a vehicle to which subsection (2) applies and in respect of which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the name and address of the keeper are not recorded in the register, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any of the particulars recorded in the register are incorrect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)This subsection applies to a vehicle if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)vehicle excise duty is chargeable in respect of it, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)it is an exempt vehicle in respect of which regulations under this Act require a nil licence to be in force.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (1) to show (as the case may be)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that there was no reasonable opportunity, before the material time, to furnish the name and address of the keeper of the vehicle, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that there was no reasonable opportunity, before the material time, to furnish particulars correcting the incorrect particulars.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)It is also a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (1) to show—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that he had reasonable grounds for believing, or that it was reasonable for him to expect, that the name and address of the keeper or the other particulars of registration (as the case may be) were correctly recorded in the register, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that any exception prescribed in regulations under this section is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Secretary of State may make regulations prescribing, varying or revoking exceptions for the purposes of subsection (4)(b).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “keeper”, in relation to a vehicle, means the person by whom it is kept at the material time;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “the register” means the register kept by the Secretary of State under Part 2.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In Schedule 3 to the Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 (c. 53) (fixed penalty offences) after the entry relating to section 43 of the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Section 43C of that ActUsing an incorrectly registered vehicle.”Commencement InformationI105S. 150 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)151Power of constables etc. to require production of registration documents in respect of a vehicleU.K.After section 28 of the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994 (c. 22) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Power of constables etc. to require production of documentsU.K.28APower of constables etc. to require production of registration documents(1)A person using a vehicle in respect of which a registration document has been issued must produce the document for inspection on being so required by—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a constable, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person authorised by the Secretary of State for the purposes of this section (an “authorised person”).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An authorised person exercising the power conferred by subsection (1) must, if so requested, produce evidence of his authority to exercise the power.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person is guilty of an offence if he fails to comply with subsection (1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Subsection (3) does not apply if any of the following conditions is satisfied.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The first condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the person produces the registration document, in person, at a police station specified by him at the time of the request, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he does so within 7 days after the date on which the request was made or as soon as is reasonably practicable.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The second condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the vehicle is subject to a lease or hire agreement,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the vehicle is not registered in the name of the lessee or hirer under that agreement and is not required to be so registered,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the person produces appropriate evidence of the agreement to the constable or authorised person at the time of the request or he produces such evidence in person, at a police station specified by him at the time of the request—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)within 7 days after the date of the request, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)as soon as is reasonably practicable, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)the person has reasonable grounds for believing, or it is reasonable for him to expect, that the person from whom the vehicle has been leased or hired is able to produce, or require the production of, the registration document.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In subsection (6)(c) “appropriate evidence” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a copy of the agreement, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)such other documentary evidence of the agreement as is prescribed in regulations under this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)The third condition is that any exception prescribed in regulations under this section is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Where a requirement is imposed under subsection (1) by an authorised person, a testing station provided under section 52(2) of the Road Traffic Act 1988 may be specified under subsection (5)(a) or (6)(c) instead of a police station.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)A person accused of an offence under this section is not entitled to the benefit of an exception conferred by or under this section unless evidence is adduced that is sufficient to raise an issue with respect to that exception, but where evidence is so adduced it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the exception does not apply.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 2 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (12)The Secretary of State may make regulations—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)prescribing descriptions of evidence for the purposes of subsection (7);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)prescribing, varying or revoking exceptions for the purposes of subsection (8).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (13)In this section “registration document” means a registration document issued in accordance with regulations under section 22(1)(e).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI106S. 151 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)152Power to seize etc. vehicles driven without licence or insuranceE+W+SAfter section 165 of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (c. 52) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “165APower to seize vehicles driven without licence or insurance(1)Subsection (5) applies if any of the following conditions is satisfied.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The first condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a constable in uniform requires, under section 164, a person to produce his licence and its counterpart for examination,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the person fails to produce them, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the constable has reasonable grounds for believing that a motor vehicle is or was being driven by the person in contravention of section 87(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The second condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a constable in uniform requires, under section 165, a person to produce evidence that a motor vehicle is not or was not being driven in contravention of section 143,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the person fails to produce such evidence, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the constable has reasonable grounds for believing that the vehicle is or was being so driven.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The third condition is that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a constable in uniform requires, under section 163, a person driving a motor vehicle to stop the vehicle,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the person fails to stop the vehicle, or to stop the vehicle long enough, for the constable to make such lawful enquiries as he considers appropriate, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the constable has reasonable grounds for believing that the vehicle is or was being driven in contravention of section 87(1) or 143.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Where this subsection applies, the constable may—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)seize the vehicle in accordance with subsections (6) and (7) and remove it;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)enter, for the purpose of exercising a power falling within paragraph (a), any premises (other than a private dwelling house) on which he has reasonable grounds for believing the vehicle to be;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)use reasonable force, if necessary, in the exercise of any power conferred by paragraph (a) or (b).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Before seizing the motor vehicle, the constable must warn the person by whom it appears that the vehicle is or was being driven in contravention of section 87(1) or 143 that he will seize it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in a section 87(1) case, if the person does not produce his licence and its counterpart immediately;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in a section 143 case, if the person does not provide him immediately with evidence that the vehicle is not or was not being driven in contravention of that section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: But the constable is not required to give such a warning if the circumstances make it impracticable for him to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)If the constable is unable to seize the vehicle immediately because the person driving the vehicle has failed to stop as requested or has driven off, he may seize it at any time within the period of 24 hours beginning with the time at which the condition in question is first satisfied.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)The powers conferred on a constable by this section are exercisable only at a time when regulations under section 165B are in force.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a reference to a motor vehicle does not include an invalid carriage;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a reference to evidence that a motor vehicle is not or was not being driven in contravention of section 143 is a reference to a document or other evidence within section 165(2)(a);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)“counterpart” and “licence” have the same meanings as in section 164;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)“private dwelling house” does not include any garage or other structure occupied with the dwelling house, or any land appurtenant to the dwelling house.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 165BRetention etc. of vehicles seized under section 165A(1)The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision as to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the removal and retention of motor vehicles seized under section 165A; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the release or disposal of such motor vehicles.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Regulations under subsection (1) may, in particular, make provision—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)for the giving of notice of the seizure of a motor vehicle under section 165A to a person who is the registered keeper, the owner or the driver of that vehicle;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)for the procedure by which a person who claims to be the registered keeper or the owner of a motor vehicle seized under section 165A may seek to have it released;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)for requiring the payment, by the registered keeper, owner or driver of the vehicle, of fees, charges or costs in relation to the removal and retention of such a motor vehicle and to any application for its release;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)as to the circumstances in which a motor vehicle seized under section 165A may be disposed of;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)as to the destination—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)of any fees or charges payable in accordance with the regulations;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)of the proceeds (if any) arising from the disposal of a motor vehicle seized under section 165A;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)for the delivery to a local authority, in circumstances prescribed by or determined in accordance with the regulations, of any motor vehicle seized under section 165A.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Regulations under subsection (1) must provide that a person who would otherwise be liable to pay any fee or charge under the regulations is not liable to pay it if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)he was not driving the motor vehicle at the time in question, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)he did not know that the vehicle was being driven at that time, had not consented to its being driven and could not, by the taking of reasonable steps, have prevented it from being driven.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Regulations under subsection (1) may make different provision for different cases.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “local authority”—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in relation to England, means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)a county council,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)the council of a district comprised in an area for which there is no county council,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iii)a London borough council,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iv)the Common Council of the City of London, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (v)Transport for London;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in relation to Wales, means the council of a county or county borough; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)in relation to Scotland, means a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc. (Scotland) Act 1994;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “registered keeper”, in relation to a motor vehicle, means the person in whose name the vehicle is registered under the Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI107S. 152 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)153Disclosure of information about insurance status of vehiclesE+W+S(1)The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for and in connection with requiring MIIC to make available relevant vehicle insurance information to [F130the Secretary of State for processing] with a view to making the processed information available for use by constables.

Text: (a)require all relevant vehicle insurance information or any particular description of such information to be made available to [F132the Secretary of State],
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)determine the purposes for which information processed from such information by [F132the Secretary of State] may be made available for use by constables, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)determine the circumstances in which any of the processed information which has been made available for use by constables may be further disclosed by them.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “information” means information held in any form,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “MIIC” means the Motor Insurers' Information Centre (a company limited by guarantee and incorporated under the Companies Act 1985 (c. 6) on 8th December 1998), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF130Words in s. 153(1) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(2); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F131Words in s. 153(2) omitted (1.11.2019) by virtue of The Motor Vehicles (Compulsory Insurance) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2019 (S.I. 2019/1047), reg. 1, Sch. 1 para. 33 (with reg. 5)F132Words in s. 153(3)(a)(b) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(3); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F133Words in s. 153(4) omitted (7.10.2013) by virtue of Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(4); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)Commencement InformationI108S. 153 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)154Power to require specimens of breath at roadside or at hospital etc.E+W(1)Section 6D of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (preliminary tests for drink and drugs: arrest) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)After subsection (1) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)The fact that specimens of breath have been provided under section 7 of this Act by the person concerned does not prevent subsection (1) above having effect if the constable who imposed on him the requirement to provide the specimens has reasonable cause to believe that the device used to analyse the specimens has not produced a reliable indication of the proportion of alcohol in the breath of the person.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)After subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)A person arrested under this section may, instead of being taken to a police station, be detained at or near the place where the preliminary test was, or would have been, administered, with a view to imposing on him there a requirement under section 7 of this Act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Section 7 of that Act (provision of specimens for analysis) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)For subsection (2) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2)A requirement under this section to provide specimens of breath can only be made—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)at a police station,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)at a hospital, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)at or near a place where a relevant breath test has been administered to the person concerned or would have been so administered but for his failure to co-operate with it.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2A)For the purposes of this section “a relevant breath test” is a procedure involving the provision by the person concerned of a specimen of breath to be used for the purpose of obtaining an indication whether the proportion of alcohol in his breath or blood is likely to exceed the prescribed limit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2B)A requirement under this section to provide specimens of breath may not be made at or near a place mentioned in subsection (2)(c) above unless the constable making it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)is in uniform, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)has imposed a requirement on the person concerned to co-operate with a relevant breath test in circumstances in which section 6(5) of this Act applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2C)Where a constable has imposed a requirement on the person concerned to co-operate with a relevant breath test at any place, he is entitled to remain at or near that place in order to impose on him there a requirement under this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2D)If a requirement under subsection (1)(a) above has been made at a place other than at a police station, such a requirement may subsequently be made at a police station if (but only if)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a device or a reliable device of the type mentioned in subsection (1)(a) above was not available at that place or it was for any other reason not practicable to use such a device there, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the constable who made the previous requirement has reasonable cause to believe that the device used there has not produced a reliable indication of the proportion of alcohol in the breath of the person concerned.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In subsection (3) (circumstances in which requirement to provide a specimen of blood or urine may be made)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in paragraph (b) (breath-testing device not available etc.) insert at the beginning “ specimens of breath have not been provided elsewhere and ”, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in paragraph (bb) (police station breath-testing device has not provided a reliable indication of alcohol level) for “at the police station” substitute “ (at the police station or elsewhere) ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)In section 9(1) of that Act (protection for hospital patients) for “for a laboratory test” substitute “ under section 7 of this Act ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Section 10 of that Act (detention of persons affected by alcohol or a drug) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)In subsection (1) (detention at a police station)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)for “until it appears to the constable” substitute “ (or, if the specimen was provided otherwise than at a police station, arrested and taken to and detained at a police station) if a constable has reasonable grounds for believing ”, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)for “not be committing” substitute “ commit ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)In subsection (2) (grounds for detention) for “A person shall not be detained in pursuance of this section if it appears to a” substitute “ Subsection (1) above does not apply to the person if it ought reasonably to appear to the ”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (12)After that subsection insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)A person who is at a hospital as a patient shall not be arrested and taken from there to a police station in pursuance of this section if it would be prejudicial to his proper care and treatment as a patient.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Textual AmendmentsF134S. 154(7) omitted (10.4.2015) by virtue of Deregulation Act 2015 (c. 20), s. 115(7), Sch. 11 para. 1(4); S.I. 2015/994, art. 4Commencement InformationI109S. 154 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)155Payments by Secretary of State to [F135local policing body] in relation to the prevention, detection and enforcement of certain traffic offencesE+W(1)The Secretary of State may make payments in respect of the whole or any part of the expenditure of a [F136local policing body] in relation to—

Text: Vehicle Excise and Registration Act 1994 (c. 22)section 33 (not exhibiting vehicle licence);

Text: section 42 (not fixing registration mark);

Text: section 43 (obscured registration mark);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: section 43C (using an incorrectly registered vehicle);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The Secretary of State may by order amend the list of offences in subsection (3) so as to add, modify or omit any entry.

Text: (5)In subsection (3) “construction and use requirements” has the meaning given by section 41(7) of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (c. 52).
