Text: Textual AmendmentsF138Words in s. 156 title substituted (1.4.2013) by The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(14)(a)F139Words in s. 156(1) substituted (1.4.2013) by The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(14)(b)F140Words in s. 156(3) omitted (1.11.2019) by virtue of The Motor Vehicles (Compulsory Insurance) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2019 (S.I. 2019/1047), reg. 1, Sch. 1 para. 35 (with reg. 5)Commencement InformationI111S. 156 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.S.I. 2005/358, art. 2(b)Local policing informationE+W157Publication of local policing informationE+WAfter section 8 of the Police Act 1996 (c. 16) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “8ALocal policing summaries(1)As soon as possible after the end of each financial year, every police authority established under section 3 shall issue a report for members of the public in the authority's area on matters relating to the policing of that area for the year.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Such a report is referred to in this section as a “local policing summary”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The Secretary of State may by order specify matters which are to be included in a local policing summary.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A police authority shall arrange—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)for every local policing summary issued by it under this section to be published in such manner as appears to it to be appropriate, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)for a copy of every such summary to be sent, by whatever means appear to the authority to be appropriate, to each person liable to pay any tax, precept or levy to or in respect of the authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)It shall be the duty of a police authority, in preparing and publishing a local policing summary, to have regard to any guidance given by the Secretary of State about the form and content of local policing summaries and the manner of their publication.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Before making an order under subsection (3), and before giving any such guidance as is referred to in subsection (5), the Secretary of State must consult—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)persons whom he considers to represent the interests of police authorities,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)persons whom he considers to represent the interests of chief officers of police, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)such other persons as he thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)This section shall apply in relation to the Metropolitan Police Authority as it applies to a police authority established under section 3.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (3) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI112S. 157 in force at 1.4.2006 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 5(2)Other miscellaneous police mattersE+W+S158Responsibilities in relation to the health and safety etc. of policeE+W+S(1)In section 51A of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (c. 37) (application of Part 1 of that Act to police) after subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)For the purposes of this Part the relevant officer, as defined by subsection (2)(a) or (c) above, shall be treated as a corporation sole.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2B)Where, in a case in which the relevant officer, as so defined, is guilty of an offence by virtue of this section, it is proved—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that the officer-holder personally consented to the commission of the offence,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that he personally connived in its commission, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that the commission of the offence was attributable to personal neglect on his part,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the office-holder (as well as the corporation sole) shall be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2C)In subsection (2B) above “the office-holder”, in relation to the relevant officer, means an individual who, at the time of the consent, connivance or neglect—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)held the office or other position mentioned in subsection (2) above as the office or position of that officer; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)was for the time being responsible for exercising and performing the powers and duties of that office or position.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2D)The provisions mentioned in subsection (2E) below (which impose the same liability for unlawful conduct of constables on persons having their direction or control as would arise if the constables were employees of those persons) do not apply to any liability by virtue of this Part.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2E)Those provisions are—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)section 39 of the Police (Scotland) Act 1967;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)section 88(1) of the Police Act 1996;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)section 97(9) of that Act;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)paragraph 7(1) of Schedule 8 to the Police Act 1997;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)paragraph 14(1) of Schedule 3 to the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)section 28 of the Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2F)In the application of this section to Scotland—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)subsection (2A) shall have effect as if for the words “corporation sole” there were substituted “ distinct juristic person (that is to say, as a juristic person distinct from the individual who for the time being is the office-holder) ”;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)subsection (2B) shall have effect as if for the words “corporation sole” there were substituted “ juristic person ”; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)subsection (2C) shall have effect as if for the words “subsection (2B)” there were substituted “ subsections (2A) and (2B) ”.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)For subsection (2) of each of the following sections of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (c. 18)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)section 49A (right of police officers not to suffer detriment in relation to health and safety issues), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)section 134A (right of police officers not to be unfairly dismissed in relation to health and safety issues),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: substitute the subsection set out in subsection (3) of this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The subsection to be substituted is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2)In this section “the relevant officer”, in relation to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a person holding the office of constable, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a person holding an appointment as a police cadet,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: means the person who under section 51A of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 is to be treated as his employer for the purposes of Part 1 of that Act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The following provisions of the Police Reform Act 2002 (c. 30) (which relate to duties and rights in relation to the health and safety of police) cease to have effect—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)section 95, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in Schedule 8, the reference to section 5 of the Police (Health and Safety) Act 1997 (c. 42).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The amendments made by subsections (1) to (3) have effect for the purposes of any proceedings in or before a court or tribunal that are commenced on or after the day on which this Act is passed as if the amendments had come into force on 1st July 1998.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For the purposes of proceedings commenced against a person in his capacity by virtue of this section as a corporation sole (or, in Scotland, as a distinct juristic person) anything done by or in relation to that person before the passing of this Act shall be deemed to have been done by or in relation to that person in that capacity.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)No person shall be liable by virtue of section 51A(2B) of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (c. 37) in respect of anything occurring before the passing of this Act.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 159Investigations: accelerated procedure in special casesE+WSchedule 11 (which makes provision for an accelerated procedure for certain investigations into the conduct of police officers) has effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI113S. 159 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(v)160Investigations: deaths and serious injuries during or after contact with the policeE+WSchedule 12 (which makes provision for the investigation of deaths and serious injuries which occur during or after contact with persons serving with the police) has effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI114S. 160 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)Royal Parks etc.E+W161Abolition of Royal Parks ConstabularyE+W(1)The Royal Parks Constabulary is abolished.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Every relevant person shall cease to be a park constable on the appointed day.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Subsection (2) is not to be taken as terminating the Crown employment of any relevant person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In this section, section 162 and Schedule 13—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “appointed day” means such day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint for the purposes of this section,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Crown employment” has the same meaning as in the Employment Rights Act 1996 (c. 18), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “relevant person” means a person who immediately before the appointed day is serving as a park constable with the Royal Parks Constabulary.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Schedule 13 (which provides for transfers to the Metropolitan Police Authority and makes amendments) has effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI115S. 161(1) in force at 8.5.2006 by S.I. 2006/1085, art. 2(a)I116S. 161(2)-(5) in force at 1.7.2005 for specified purposes by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(x)I117S. 161(2)-(4) in force at 1.8.2005 in so far as not already in force by S.I. 2005/2026, art. 2(e)I118S. 161(5) in force at 8.5.2006 in so far as not already in force by S.I. 2006/1085, art. 2(a)162Regulation of specified parksE+W(1)From the appointed day the Parks Regulation Act 1872 (c. 15) does not apply to the specified parks.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)But from the appointed day section 2 of the Parks Regulation (Amendment) Act 1926 (c. 36) applies in relation to the specified parks in the same way as it applies in relation to parks to which the Parks Regulation Act 1872 applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The Secretary of State must ensure that copies of any regulations made under section 2 of the Parks Regulation (Amendment) Act 1926 (c. 36) which are in force in relation to a specified park are displayed in a suitable position in that park.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In this section “specified park” means a park, garden, recreation ground, open space or other land in the metropolitan police district—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)which is specified in an order made by the Secretary of State before the appointed day, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to which the Parks Regulation Act 1872 (c. 15) then applied by virtue of section 1 of the Parks Regulation (Amendment) Act 1926.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI119S. 162(1)(2)(4) in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(z)Criminal record checksU.K.163Criminal record certificatesU.K.(1)Sections 113 and 115 of the Police Act 1997 (c. 50) (criminal record certificates) are omitted.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Before section 114 of that Act insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “113ACriminal record certificates(1)The Secretary of State must issue a criminal record certificate to any individual who—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)makes an application in the prescribed manner and form, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)pays in the prescribed manner any prescribed fee.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The application must—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)be countersigned by a registered person, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)be accompanied by a statement by the registered person that the certificate is required for the purposes of an exempted question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A criminal record certificate is a certificate which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)gives the prescribed details of every relevant matter relating to the applicant which is recorded in central records, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)states that there is no such matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The Secretary of State must send a copy of a criminal record certificate to the registered person who countersigned the application.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may treat an application under this section as an application under section 113B if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)in his opinion the certificate is required for a purpose prescribed under subsection (2) of that section,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the registered person provides him with the statement required by that subsection, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the applicant consents and pays to the Secretary of State the amount (if any) by which the fee payable in relation to an application under that section exceeds the fee paid in relation to the application under this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “central records” means such records of convictions and cautions held for the use of police forces generally as may be prescribed;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “exempted question” means a question in relation to which section 4(2)(a) or (b) of the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 (effect of rehabilitation) has been excluded by an order of the Secretary of State under section 4(4) of that Act;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “relevant matter” means—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a conviction within the meaning of the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974, including a spent conviction, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a caution.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 113BEnhanced criminal record certificates(1)The Secretary of State must issue an enhanced criminal record certificate to any individual who—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)makes an application in the prescribed manner and form, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)pays in the prescribed manner any prescribed fee.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The application must—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)be countersigned by a registered person, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)be accompanied by a statement by the registered person that the certificate is required for a prescribed purpose.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An enhanced criminal record certificate is a certificate which—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)gives the prescribed details of every relevant matter relating to the applicant which is recorded in central records and any information provided in accordance with subsection (4), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)states that there is no such matter or information.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Before issuing an enhanced criminal record certificate the Secretary of State must request the chief officer of every relevant police force to provide any information which, in the chief officer's opinion—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)might be relevant for the purpose described in the statement under subsection (2), and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)ought to be included in the certificate.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State must also request the chief officer of every relevant police force to provide any information which, in the chief officer's opinion—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)might be relevant for the purpose described in the statement under subsection (2),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)ought not to be included in the certificate, in the interests of the prevention or detection of crime, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)can, without harming those interests, be disclosed to the registered person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The Secretary of State must send to the registered person who countersigned the application—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a copy of the enhanced criminal record certificate, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any information provided in accordance with subsection (5).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The Secretary of State may treat an application under this section as an application under section 113A if in his opinion the certificate is not required for a purpose prescribed under subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)If by virtue of subsection (7) the Secretary of State treats an application under this section as an application under section 113A, he must refund to the applicant the amount (if any) by which the fee paid in relation to the application under this section exceeds the fee payable in relation to an application under section 113A.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “central records”, “exempted question”, and “relevant matter” have the same meaning as in section 113A;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “relevant police force”, in relation to an application under this section, means a police force which is a relevant police force in relation to that application under regulations made by the Secretary of State.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)For the purposes of this section references to a police force include any of the following—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the Royal Navy Regulating Branch;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the Royal Marines Police;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the Royal Military Police;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)the Royal Air Force Police;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)the Ministry of Defence Police;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)the National Criminal Intelligence Service;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (g)the National Crime Squad;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (h)the British Transport Police;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)the Civil Nuclear Constabulary;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (j)the States of Jersey Police Force;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (k)the salaried police force of the Island of Guernsey;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (l)the Isle of Man Constabulary;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (m)a body with functions in any country or territory outside the British Islands which correspond to those of a police force in any part of the United Kingdom,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: and any reference to the chief officer of a police force includes the person responsible for the direction of a body mentioned in this subsection.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)For the purposes of this section each of the following must be treated as if it were a police force—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the Commissioners for Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (and for this purpose a reference to the chief officer of a police force must be taken to be a reference to any one of the Commissioners);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the Serious Organised Crime Agency (and for this purpose a reference to the chief officer of a police force must be taken to be a reference to the Director General of the Agency);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)such other department or body as is prescribed (and regulations may prescribe in relation to the department or body the person to whom a reference to the chief officer is to be taken to be).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 113CCriminal record certificates: suitability relating to children(1)If an application under section 113A or 113B is accompanied by a children's suitability statement the criminal record certificate or enhanced criminal record certificate (as the case may be) must also state—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)whether the applicant is included in a specified children's list;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)if he is included in such a list, such details of his inclusion as may be prescribed;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)whether he is subject to a specified children's direction;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)if he is subject to such a direction, the grounds on which it was given and such details as may be prescribed of the circumstances in which it was given.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A children's suitability statement is a statement by the registered person that the certificate is required for the purpose of considering—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the applicant's suitability to be employed, supplied to work, found work or given work in a position (whether paid or unpaid) within subsection (5),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the applicant's suitability to be a foster parent or to adopt a child,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the applicant's suitability to be a child's special guardian for the purposes of sections 14A and 14C of the Children Act 1989,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)the applicant's suitability to have a child placed with him by virtue of section 70 of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995 or by virtue of section 5(2), (3) and (4) of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)the suitability of a person living in the same household as the applicant to be a person mentioned in paragraph (b) or (c) or to have a child placed with him as mentioned in paragraph (d).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Each of the following is a specified children's list—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the list kept under section 1 of the Protection of Children Act 1999;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the list kept under section 1(1) of the Protection of Children (Scotland) Act 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the list kept under Article 3 of the Protection of Children and Vulnerable Adults (Northern Ireland) Order 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)any list kept for the purposes of regulations under Article 70(2)(e) or 88A(2)(b) of the Education and Libraries (Northern Ireland) Order 1986;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)any such other list as the Secretary of State specifies by order if he thinks that the list corresponds to a list specified in paragraphs (a) to (c) and is kept in pursuance of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Each of the following is a specified children's direction—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a direction under section 142 of the Education Act 2002;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)anything which the Secretary of State specifies by order which he thinks corresponds to such a direction and which is done for the purposes of the law of Scotland or of Northern Ireland or of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A position falls within this subsection if it is any of the following—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a child care position within the meaning of the Protection of Children Act 1999;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a child care position within the meaning of the Protection of Children (Scotland) Act 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)a child care position within the meaning of Chapter 1 of Part 2 of the Protection of Children and Vulnerable Adults (Northern Ireland) Order 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)a position, employment or further employment in which may be prohibited or restricted by regulations under Article 70(2)(e) or 88A(2)(b) of the Education and Libraries (Northern Ireland) Order 1986;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)a position which involves work to which section 142 of the Education Act 2002 applies;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)a position of such other description as may be prescribed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)An order under subsection (4)(b) may make such modifications of subsection (1)(d) as the Secretary of State thinks necessary or expedient in consequence of the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 113DCriminal record certificates: suitability relating to adults(1)If an application under section 113A or 113B is accompanied by an adults' suitability statement the criminal record certificate or enhanced criminal record certificate (as the case may be) must also state—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)whether the applicant is included in a specified adults' list;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)if he is included in such a list, such details of his inclusion as may be prescribed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An adults' suitability statement is a statement by the registered person that the certificate is required for the purpose of considering the applicant's suitability to be employed, supplied to work, found work or given work in a position (whether paid or unpaid) falling within subsection (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Each of the following is a specified adults' list—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the list kept under section 81 of the Care Standards Act 2000;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the list kept under Article 35 of the Protection of Children and Vulnerable Adults (Northern Ireland) Order 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)any such other list as the Secretary of State specifies by order if he thinks that the list corresponds to a list specified in paragraph (a) or (b) and is kept in pursuance of the law of Scotland or of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A position falls within this subsection if it is any of the following—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a care position within the meaning of Part 7 of the Care Standards Act 2000;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a care position within the meaning of Part 3 of the Protection of Children and Vulnerable Adults (Northern Ireland) Order 2003;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)a position concerned with providing a care service (as defined by section 2(1) of the Regulation of Care (Scotland) Act 2001);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)a position of such other description as may be prescribed.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 113ECriminal record certificates: specified children's and adults' lists: urgent cases(1)Subsection (2) applies to an application under section 113A or 113B if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it is accompanied by a children's suitability statement,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the registered person requests an urgent preliminary response, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the applicant pays in the prescribed manner such additional fee as is prescribed in respect of the application.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The Secretary of State must notify the registered person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)if the applicant is not included in a specified children's list, of that fact;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)if the applicant is included in such a list, of the details prescribed for the purposes of section 113C(1)(b) above;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)if the applicant is not subject to a specified children's direction, of that fact;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)if the applicant is subject to such a direction, of the grounds on which the direction was given and the details prescribed for the purposes of section 113C(1)(d) above.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Subsection (4) applies to an application under section 113A or 113B if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it is accompanied by an adults' suitability statement,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the registered person requests an urgent preliminary response, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)the applicant pays in the prescribed manner such additional fee as is prescribed in respect of the application.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The Secretary of State must notify the registered person either—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that the applicant is not included in a specified adults' list, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that a criminal record certificate or enhanced criminal record certificate will be issued in due course.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In this section—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “criminal record certificate” has the same meaning as in section 113A;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “enhanced criminal record certificate” has the same meaning as in section 113B;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “children's suitability statement” “, specified children's direction” and “specified children's list” have the same meaning as in section 113C;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “adults' suitability statement” and “specified adults' list” have the same meaning as in section 113D.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 113FCriminal record certificates: supplementary(1)References in sections 113C(2) and 113D(2) to considering the applicant's suitability to be employed, supplied to work, found work or given work in a position falling within section 113C(5) or 113D(4) include references to considering—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)for the purposes of Part 10A of the Children Act 1989 (child minding and day care in England and Wales), the applicant's suitability to look after or be in regular contact with children under the age of eight;

Text: Commencement InformationI224Sch. 6 para. 9 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)10E+WBefore section 248 (and its heading) insert the following heading— “ Property freezing orders and interim receiving orders: registration ”Commencement InformationI225Sch. 6 para. 10 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)11(1)Section 248 (registration: England and Wales) is amended as follows.E+W(2)In subsection (1)(a), for “interim receiving orders” substitute “ property freezing orders, and in relation to interim receiving orders, ”.(3)In subsection (1)(b), for “interim receiving orders” substitute “ property freezing orders, and in relation to applications for interim receiving orders, ”.(4)In subsection (3), before “an interim receiving order” insert “ a property freezing order or ”.Commencement InformationI226Sch. 6 para. 11 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)12(1)Section 249 (registration: Northern Ireland) is amended as follows.E+W(2)In subsection (1), after “applying for” insert “ a property freezing order or ”.(3)In subsection (1)(b), for “an interim receiving order” substitute “ a property freezing order, or an interim receiving order, ”.(4)After subsection (1) insert—“(1A)Upon being served with a copy of a property freezing order, the Registrar must, in respect of any registered land to which a property freezing order or an application for a property freezing order relates, make an entry inhibiting any dealing with the land without the consent of the High Court.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)In subsection (3), after “entry made under subsection” insert “ (1A) or ”.(6)In subsection (4)—(a)after “Where” insert “ a property freezing order or ”, and(b)after “setting aside the” insert “ property freezing order or ”.Commencement InformationI227Sch. 6 para. 12 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)13E+WBefore section 250 (and its heading) insert the following heading— “ Interim receiving orders: further provisions ”Commencement InformationI228Sch. 6 para. 13 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)14(1)Section 252 (interim receiving orders: prohibition on dealings) is amended as follows.E+W(2)For subsection (4) (restriction on exclusions for legal expenses) substitute—“(4)Where the court exercises the power to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses that he has incurred, or may incur, in respect of proceedings under this Part, it must ensure that the exclusion—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)is limited to reasonable legal expenses that the person has reasonably incurred or that he reasonably incurs,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)specifies the total amount that may be released for legal expenses in pursuance of the exclusion, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)is made subject to the required conditions (see section 286A) in addition to any conditions imposed under subsection (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4A)The court, in deciding whether to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses of his in respect of proceedings under this Part—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)must have regard (in particular) to the desirability of the person being represented in any proceedings under this Part in which he is a participant, and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)must, where the person is the respondent, disregard the possibility that legal representation of the person in any such proceedings might, were an exclusion not made, be funded by the Legal Services Commission or the Northern Ireland Legal Services Commission.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In subsection (6) (power to make exclusions not to be exercised so as to prejudice enforcement authority's rights to recover property), after “must” insert “ , subject to subsection (4A), ”.Commencement InformationI229Sch. 6 para. 14 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)15E+WIn section 266 (recovery orders), after subsection (8) insert—“(8A)A recovery order made by a court in England and Wales or Northern Ireland may provide for payment under section 280 of reasonable legal expenses that a person has reasonably incurred, or may reasonably incur, in respect of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the proceedings under this Part in which the order is made, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any related proceedings under this Part.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8B)If regulations under section 286B apply to an item of expenditure, a sum in respect of the item is not payable under section 280 in pursuance of provision under subsection (8A) unless—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the enforcement authority agrees to its payment, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the court has assessed the amount allowed by the regulations in respect of that item and the sum is paid in respect of the assessed amount.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI230Sch. 6 para. 15 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)16E+WIn section 271(4) (certain payments to trustee for civil recovery to be reduced to take account of loss caused by interim receiving order etc.)—(a)in paragraph (a), for “an interim receiving order or” substitute “ a property freezing order, an interim receiving order, a prohibitory property order or an ”, and(b)in paragraph (b), for “interim receiving order or interim administration order” substitute “ order mentioned in paragraph (a) ”.Commencement InformationI231Sch. 6 para. 16 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)17E+WIn section 272(5) (provision in recovery orders for compensation for loss caused by interim receiving order etc.)—(a)in paragraph (a), for “an interim receiving order or” substitute “ a property freezing order, an interim receiving order, a prohibitory property order or an ”, and(b)in paragraph (b), for “interim receiving order or interim administration order” substitute “ order mentioned in paragraph (a) ”.Commencement InformationI232Sch. 6 para. 17 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)18E+WIn section 280(2) (application of realised proceeds of recovery order)—(a)after paragraph (a) insert—“(aa)next, any payment of legal expenses which, after giving effect to section 266(8B), are payable under this subsection in pursuance of provision under section 266(8A) contained in the recovery order,” and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)in paragraph (b), for “second” substitute “ then ”.Commencement InformationI233Sch. 6 para. 18 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)19E+WIn section 283 (compensation where interim receiving order etc. has applied)—(a)in subsection (1), for “an interim receiving order or” substitute “ a property freezing order, an interim receiving order, a prohibitory property order or an ”, and(b)in subsection (5), for “interim receiving order or interim administration order” substitute “ order mentioned in subsection (1) ”.Commencement InformationI234Sch. 6 para. 19 in force at 1.1.2006 by S.I. 2005/3136, art. 3(c)20E+WAfter section 286 insert—“286ALegal expenses excluded from freezing: required conditions(1)The Lord Chancellor may by regulations specify the required conditions for the purposes of section 245C(5) or 252(4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A required condition may (in particular)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)restrict who may receive sums released in pursuance of the exclusion (by, for example, requiring released sums to be paid to professional legal advisers), or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)be made for the purpose of controlling the amount of any sum released in pursuance of the exclusion in respect of an item of expenditure.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A required condition made for the purpose mentioned in subsection (2)(b) may (for example)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)provide for sums to be released only with the agreement of the enforcement authority;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)provide for a sum to be released in respect of an item of expenditure only if the court has assessed the amount allowed by regulations under section 286B in respect of that item and the sum is released for payment of the assessed amount;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)provide for a sum to be released in respect of an item of expenditure only if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)the enforcement authority agrees to its release, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)the court has assessed the amount allowed by regulations under section 286B in respect of that item and the sum is released for payment of the assessed amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Before making regulations under this section, the Lord Chancellor must consult such persons as he considers appropriate.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 286BLegal expenses: regulations for purposes of section 266(8B) or 286A(3)(1)The Lord Chancellor may by regulations—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)make provision for the purposes of section 266(8B);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)make provision for the purposes of required conditions that make provision of the kind mentioned in section 286A(3)(b) or (c).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Regulations under this section may (in particular)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)limit the amount of remuneration allowable to representatives for a unit of time worked;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)limit the total amount of remuneration allowable to representatives for work done in connection with proceedings or a step in proceedings;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)limit the amount allowable in respect of an item of expense incurred by a representative or incurred, otherwise than in respect of the remuneration of a representative, by a party to proceedings.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Before making regulations under this section, the Lord Chancellor must consult such persons as he considers appropriate.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)under subsection (1) of section 165 of the Road Traffic Act 1988 to require a person mentioned in paragraph (c) of that subsection who he has reasonable cause to believe has committed, in the relevant police area, an offence under subsection (1) or (2) of section 35 of that Act (including that section as extended by paragraphs 8B(4) and 9(2) of this Schedule) to give his name and address; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI303Sch. 8 para. 19 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(i)20E+WAfter paragraph 8A insert—“8B“Power to control traffic for purposes other than escorting a load of exceptional dimensions(1)A person whose accreditation specifies that this paragraph applies to him shall have, in the relevant police area—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the power of a constable engaged in the regulation of traffic in a road to direct a person driving or propelling a vehicle to stop the vehicle or to make it proceed in, or keep to, a particular line of traffic;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the power of a constable in uniform engaged in the regulation of vehicular traffic in a road to direct a person on foot to stop proceeding along or across the carriageway.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The purposes for which those powers may be exercised do not include the purpose mentioned in paragraph 9(1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person whose accreditation specifies that this paragraph applies to him shall also have, in the relevant police area, the power of a constable, for the purposes of a traffic survey, to direct a person driving or propelling a vehicle to stop the vehicle, to make it proceed in, or keep to, a particular line of traffic, or to proceed to a particular point on or near the road.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Sections 35 and 37 of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (offences of failing to comply with directions of constable engaged in regulation of traffic in a road) shall have effect in relation to the exercise of the powers mentioned in sub-paragraphs (1) and (3), for the purposes for which they may be exercised and by a person whose accreditation specifies that this paragraph applies to him, as if the references to a constable were references to him.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person's accreditation may not specify that this paragraph applies to him unless it also specifies that paragraph 3A applies to him.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI304Sch. 8 para. 20 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(i)21E+WAfter paragraph 9 insert—“9ZA“Photographing of persons given fixed penalty noticesAn accredited person whose accreditation specifies that this paragraph applies to him shall, within the relevant police area, have the power of a constable under section 64A(1A) of the 1984 Act (photographing of suspects etc.) to take a photograph, elsewhere than at a police station, of a person to whom the accredited person has given a penalty notice (or as the case may be a fixed penalty notice) in exercise of any power mentioned in paragraph 1(2).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

S.I. 2017/1139, reg. 2(k) (as amended by S.I. 2017/1162, reg. 2)Detention officersE+W7E+WAfter paragraph 33A (inserted by paragraph 16 of Schedule 8 to this Act) insert—“Powers in respect of detained personsE+W33BWhere a designation applies this paragraph to any person, he shall be under a duty, when in the course of his employment he is present at a police station—(a)to keep under control any person detained at the police station and for whom he is for the time being responsible;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)to assist any officer or other designated person to keep any other person detained at the police station under control; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)to prevent the escape of any such person as is mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b),
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: and for those purposes shall be entitled to use reasonable force.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Powers in respect of detained personsE+W33CWhere a designation applies this paragraph to any person, he shall be entitled to use reasonable force when—(a)securing, or assisting an officer or another designated person to secure, the detention of a person detained at a police station in the relevant police area, or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)escorting within a police station in the relevant police area, or assisting an officer or another designated person to escort within such a police station, a person detained there.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI307Sch. 9 para. 7 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(j)Escort officersE+W8(1)Paragraph 34 (power to take an arrested person to a police station) is amended as follows.E+W(2)In sub-paragraph (1)(c)—(a)in paragraph (ii), after “duty” insert “ to keep the person under control and ”,(b)in paragraph (iii), at the end add “ and under his control ”.(3)After sub-paragraph (1)(c) add—“(d)a person who has taken another person to a police station in exercise of the power conferred by virtue of paragraph (a)—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (i)shall be under a duty to remain at the police station until he has transferred control of the other person to the custody officer at the police station;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)until he has so transferred control of the other person, shall be treated for all purposes as having that person in his lawful custody;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iii)for so long as he is at the police station or in its immediate vicinity in compliance with, or having complied with, his duty under sub-paragraph (i), shall be under a duty to prevent the escape of the other person and to assist in keeping him under control; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (iv)shall be entitled to use reasonable force for the purpose of complying with his duty under sub-paragraph (iii).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI308Sch. 9 para. 8 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(j)9(1)Paragraph 35 (escort of persons in police detention) is amended as follows.E+W(2)In sub-paragraph (3)—(a)in paragraph (b), after “duty” insert “ to keep the person under control and ”,(b)in paragraph (c), at the end add “ and under his control ”.(3)After sub-paragraph (3) insert—“(3A)A person who has escorted another person to a police station or other place in accordance with an authorisation under sub-paragraph (1) or (2) —
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)shall be under a duty to remain at the police station or other place until he has transferred control of the other person to a custody officer or other responsible person there;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)until he has so transferred control of the other person, shall be treated for all purposes as having that person in his lawful custody;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)for so long as he is at the police station or other place, or in its immediate vicinity, in compliance with, or having complied with, his duty under paragraph (a), shall be under a duty to prevent the escape of the other person and to assist in keeping him under control; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)shall be entitled to use reasonable force for the purpose of complying with his duty under paragraph (c).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI309Sch. 9 para. 9 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(j)ProspectiveStaff custody officersE+WF18910E+W. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .Textual AmendmentsF189Sch. 9 para. 10 repealed (12.1.2009) by Policing and Crime Act 2009 (c. 26), s. 116(6)(b), Sch. 8 Pt. 13Section 144SCHEDULE 10E+W+N.I.Parental compensation orders Part 1 E+WEngland and Wales1E+WThe Crime and Disorder Act 1998 (c. 37) is amended as provided in paragraphs 2 to 5.Commencement InformationI310Sch. 10 para. 1 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 22E+WAfter section 13 insert—“13AParental compensation orders(1)A magistrates' court may make an order under this section (a “parental compensation order”) if on the application of a local authority it is satisfied, on the civil standard of proof—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)that the condition mentioned in subsection (2) below is fulfilled with respect to a child under the age of 10; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)that it would be desirable to make the order in the interests of preventing a repetition of the behaviour in question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The condition is that the child has taken, or caused loss of or damage to, property in the course of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)committing an act which, if he had been aged 10 or over, would have constituted an offence; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)acting in a manner that caused or was likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to one or more persons not of the same household as himself.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A parental compensation order is an order which requires any person specified in the order who is a parent or guardian of the child (other than a local authority) to pay compensation of an amount specified in the order to any person or persons specified in the order who is, or are, affected by the taking of the property or its loss or damage.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The amount of compensation specified may not exceed £5,000 in all.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (4) above so as to substitute a different amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For the purposes of collection and enforcement, a parental compensation order is to be treated as if it were a sum adjudged to be paid on the conviction by the magistrates' court which made the order of the person or persons specified in the order as liable to pay the compensation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section and sections 13B and 13C below, “local authority” has the same meaning as in the 1989 Act.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13BParental compensation orders: the compensation(1)When specifying the amount of compensation for the purposes of section 13A(3) above, the magistrates' court shall take into account—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the value of the property taken or damaged, or whose loss was caused, by the child;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)any further loss which flowed from the taking of or damage to the property, or from its loss;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)whether the child, or any parent or guardian of his, has already paid any compensation for the property (and if so, how much);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (d)whether the child, or any parent or guardian of his, has already made any reparation (and if so, what it consisted of);
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (e)the means of those to be specified in the order as liable to pay the compensation, so far as the court can ascertain them;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (f)whether there was any lack of care on the part of the person affected by the taking of the property or its loss or damage which made it easier for the child to take or damage the property or to cause its loss.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If property taken is recovered before compensation is ordered to be paid in respect of it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the court shall not order any such compensation to be payable in respect of it if it is not damaged;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)if it is damaged, the damage shall be treated for the purposes of making a parental compensation order as having been caused by the child, regardless of how it was caused and who caused it.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The court shall specify in the order how and by when the compensation is to be paid (for example, it may specify that the compensation is to be paid by instalments, and specify the date by which each instalment must be paid).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purpose of ascertaining the means of the parent or guardian, the court may, before specifying the amount of compensation, order him to provide the court, within such period as it may specify in the order, such a statement of his financial circumstances as the court may require.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person who without reasonable excuse fails to comply with an order under subsection (4) above is guilty of an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If, in providing a statement of his financial circumstances pursuant to an order under subsection (4) above, a person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)makes a statement which he knows to be false in a material particular;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)recklessly provides a statement which is false in a material particular; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)knowingly fails to disclose any material fact,
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Proceedings in respect of an offence under subsection (6) above may, despite anything in section 127(1) of the 1980 Act (limitation of time), be commenced at any time within two years from the date of the commission of the offence or within six months of its first discovery by the local authority, whichever period expires earlier.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13CParental compensation orders: supplemental(1)Before deciding whether or not to make a parental compensation order in favour of any person, the magistrates' court shall take into account the views of that person about whether a parental compensation order should be made in his favour.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Before making a parental compensation order, the magistrates' court shall obtain and consider information about the child's family circumstances and the likely effect of the order on those circumstances.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Before making a parental compensation order, a magistrates' court shall explain to the parent or guardian of the child in ordinary language—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)the effect of the order and of the requirements proposed to be included in it;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)the consequences which may follow (under subsection (4)(b) below) as a result of failure to comply with any of those requirements;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (c)that the court has power (under subsection (4)(a) below) to review the order on the application either of the parent or guardian or of the local authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A magistrates' court which has made a parental compensation order may make an order under subsection (5) below if while the order is in force—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)it appears to the court, on the application of the local authority, or the parent or guardian subject to the order, that it is appropriate to make an order under subsection (5); or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)it is proved to the satisfaction of the court, on the application of the local authority, that the parent or guardian subject to it has failed to comply with any requirement included in the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An order under this subsection is an order discharging the parental compensation order or varying it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)by cancelling any provision included in it; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)by inserting in it (either in addition to or in substitution for any of its provisions) any provision that could have been included in the order if the court had then had power to make it and were exercising the power.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Where an application under subsection (4) above for the discharge of a parental compensation order is dismissed, no further application for its discharge shall be made under that subsection by any person except with the consent of the court which made the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)References in this section to the magistrates' court which made a parental compensation order include any magistrates' court acting in the same local justice area as that court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13DParental compensation orders: appeal(1)If a magistrates' court makes a parental compensation order, the parent or guardian may appeal against the making of the order, or against the amount of compensation specified in the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The appeal lies to the Crown Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)On the appeal the Crown Court—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)may make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to its determination of the appeal;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)may also make such incidental or consequential orders as appear to it to be just.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Any order of the Crown Court made on an appeal under this section (other than one directing that an application be re-heard by a magistrates' court) shall, for the purposes of section 13C above, be treated as if it were an order of the magistrates' court from which the appeal was brought and not an order of the Crown Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person in whose favour a parental compensation order is made shall not be entitled to receive any compensation under it until (disregarding any power of a court to grant leave to appeal out of time) there is no further possibility of an appeal on which the order could be varied or set aside.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13EEffect of parental compensation order on subsequent award of damages in civil proceedings(1)This section has effect where—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)a parental compensation order has been made in favour of any person in respect of any taking or loss of property or damage to it; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a claim by him in civil proceedings for damages in respect of the taking, loss or damage is then to be determined.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The damages in the civil proceedings shall be assessed without regard to the parental compensation order, but the claimant may recover only an amount equal to the aggregate of the following—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)any amount by which they exceed the compensation; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)a sum equal to any portion of the compensation which he fails to recover.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The claimant may not enforce the judgment, so far as it relates to such a sum as is mentioned in subsection (2)(b) above, without the permission of the court.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI311Sch. 10 para. 2 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 23(1)Section 8 (parenting orders) is amended as follows.E+W(2)In subsection (1), after paragraph (a) insert—“(aa)a parental compensation order is made in relation to a child's behaviour;”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)In subsection (6)(a)—(a)after “paragraph (a)” insert “ , (aa) ”,F190(b). . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .Textual AmendmentsF190Sch. 10 para. 3(3)(b) repealed (23.3.2015) by Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 (c. 12), s. 185(1), Sch. 11 para. 50 (with ss. 21, 33, 42, 58, 75, 93); S.I. 2015/373, art. 4(f)(xii)Commencement InformationI312Sch. 10 para. 3 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 24E+WIn section 18 (interpretation of Chapter 1), in subsection (1), after the definition of “local child curfew scheme” insert—““parental compensation order” has the meaning given by section 13A(1) above;”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI313Sch. 10 para. 4 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 25E+WIn section 114 (orders and regulations), in subsection (3), after “section” insert “ 13A(5), ”.Commencement InformationI314Sch. 10 para. 5 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 26E+WThe amendments made by paragraph 2 of this Schedule do not apply in relation to any conduct which occurred before the coming into force of that paragraph.Commencement InformationI315Sch. 10 para. 6 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 2Prospective Part 2 N.I.Northern Ireland7N.I.The Criminal Justice (Children) (Northern Ireland) Order 1998 (S.I. 1998/1504 (N.I. 9)) is amended as provided in paragraphs 8 and 9.8N.I.After Article 36 insert—“36ZAParental compensation orders(1)A magistrates' court may make an order under this Article (a “parental compensation order”) if on the application of a person of a description specified for the purpose in an order made by the Secretary of State (referred to in this Article and in Articles 36ZB and 36ZC as the “applicant”) the court is satisfied, on the civil standard of proof—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (a)committing an act which, if he had been aged 10 or over, would have constituted an offence; or
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (b)acting in a manner that caused or was likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to one or more persons not of the same household as himself.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A parental compensation order is an order which requires any person specified in the order who is a parent or guardian of the child to pay compensation of an amount specified in the order to any person or persons specified in the order who is, or are, affected by the taking of the property or its loss or damage.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The amount of compensation specified may not exceed £5,000 in all.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may by order amend paragraph (4) so as to substitute a different amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For the purposes of collection and enforcement, a parental compensation order is to be treated as if it were a sum adjudged to be paid on the conviction by the magistrates' court which made the order of the person or persons specified in the order as liable to pay the compensation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)An order under paragraph (1) or (5) is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament in the same manner as a statutory instrument; and, accordingly, section 5 of the Statutory Instruments Act 1946 (c. 36) applies to such an order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
